comments.comment:
Yeah for sure. Good question. We have some devices that can discovered with mdns. We pick one to the be "bridge". It can be any of them that are on wifi at the time. That device is then responsible for bridging tcp to ble as not all deako devices are on wifi at all times. Once a device is selected to be the bridge, it will stay on wifi as the local integration device. All other devices periodically get on wifi to check in, send logs, etc. 

Since we only really connect to one device, one config entry. All other devices are then exposed through that device using the local API.

Please don't hard pin deps in the lib. Instead use `>=`

`    vevor-heater-ble 0.0.5 depends on bleak-retry-connector~=3.2.1`
comments.author: iotmaestro

comments.comment:
> Please don't hard pin deps in the lib. Instead use `>=`
> 
> ` vevor-heater-ble 0.0.5 depends on bleak-retry-connector~=3.2.1`

I'm a little confused about what this refers to. The manifest specifies an exact version which seems to be common practice looking at other integrations, and the BLE library itself uses fuzzy version matching (https://github.com/iotmaestro/vevor-heater-ble/blob/main/pyproject.toml). Can you elaborate?
comments.author: iotmaestro

comments.comment: The manifest is the only place we want the specific version pins.  The libraries themselves should specify only a minimum version with optionally a maximum next major version (but we try to avoid this). If libraries constrain to only specific versions, than HA can never be installed because we would have hundreds of dependency conflicts which could never be solved.
comments.author: iotmaestro

comments.comment:
> The manifest is the only place we want the specific version pins. The libraries themselves should specify only a minimum version with optionally a maximum next major version (but we try to avoid this). If libraries constrain to only specific versions, than HA can never be installed because we would have hundreds of dependency conflicts which could never be solved.

I see - I read the comment the other way around (that `~=3.2.1` is the desired state). Something something 5AM wakeups. Fixed now, and also the tests. Please take another look.

Note for self: Once the PR looks ok let's not forget about updating the "introduced in" versions in this and all related PRs.

comments.comment:
> Thanks for your contribution! Initial review to get you started.
> 
> Have you tested this PR? Not sure if I overlook it, but doesn't seem you handle state updates / local polling anywhere?

This is a wifi to remote device, it can't actively know the state of the cover because there is no network connection between them, just as there is no way to ask the TV remote which channel is playing on the TV right now. We can only save the cached state values when actively controlling a wifi to IR device, and besides, cover can only be controlled by this IR device, so there's no ambiguity about it.

I have tested it and it works normally. The following is the test video I recorded, please refer to:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/103OHx1o51UTyQacpoZSluwANoZwNmG4V/view?usp=sharing
comments.author: greg-ha-1990

comments.comment: Hi, I now have 15 Leviosa shades in my house and effectively loaded this PR into my instance as this code works much better than what Leviosa has posted on their site. What's needed to get this pushed over the finish line? @greg-ha-1990 do you need help with any final changes / edits? @emontnemery I appreciate you wanting to understand how this is working, it is an odd setup. Any compromises we can make so this can get into the official release?
comments.author: greg-ha-1990

comments.comment:
As someone who purchased leviosa shades and the "leviosa zone", I appreciate work being done to make sure this new integration meets home assistant standards. I would rather wait longer for my shades to work with home assistant than load extra technical debt onto the home assistant maintainers

> The hub itself doesn't have any S/N or MAC printed on it. Just a general brand label and required FCC markings.

The "leviosa zone" is, as far as I can tell from examining mine, a repackaged IR blaster. It has a MAC address, and would require minimal effort on the part of the Leviosa team to add a sticker to it with the devices Mac address (or, worst case, users can just find it on their router as I have)
It seems silly (to me) to add a bunch of extra user pain trying to track what DHCP has assigned a device's IP to... when a simple process improvement by switching to using a universal identifier solves this problem as it's designed to
comments.author: greg-ha-1990

comments.comment: @dpiessens there are many unaddressed review comments. If @greg-ha-1990 doesn't have the time to address them, someone else needs to step up for this PR to be merged. An alternative is to publish a custom integration.
comments.author: greg-ha-1990

comments.comment:
> @dpiessens there are many unaddressed review comments. If @greg-ha-1990 doesn't have the time to address them, someone else needs to step up for this PR to be merged. An alternative is to publish a custom integration.

I didn't see this rule in the official recommended style. 

In fact, if you do a global search for the key word `: Final = ` in the core repository, you'll see that most of the results are within `const.py`.

![](https://jijiantuku-image.oss-cn-beijing.aliyuncs.com/markdown_img/2024/04/17/20240417_085218_c93c9b93158827b1a5bd4fc51ca268f3.png)

I just looked for a few other integrations as a reference. I can easily find that their constants in `const.py` have only been imported once, such as:
`ATTRIBUTION` in [adobe](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/dev/homeassistant/components/abode/const.py), which is only used in `__init__.py`, Another example is `ATTRIBUTION` in [aftership](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/dev/homeassistant/components/aftership/const.py), which is only used by `sensor.py` . You can find tons of examples of this if you want.

It should be written in const.py as long as it has the `public` constant attribute, and if it has to be set to private after being imported only once, it will inevitably make maintenance difficult, because the entity code is iterated and may be maintained by different people, and in that case, it will inevitably need a public const.py to life the public constants, which is what most integrations do.
comments.author: greg-ha-1990
greg-ha-1990

comments.comment:
Thank you for your suggestion.
My understanding is that since a leviosa shades can spawn multiple entities, this curtain controller is essentially a wifi to IR device, but it can control up to six groups of covers, so it will derive up to seven entities, such as `group1` - `group6` and `group_ALL`, so we need to call the `async_add_entities` method inside the `async_setup_entry` method, but obviously the `async_setup_entry` method in `__init__.py` doesn't have an `AddEntitiesCallback` parameter, so it's not possible to call `async_add_entities` inside `async_setup_entry` in __init__,py anymore.
I'm currently stuck at this point and don't know how to proceed from here, again I'll ask you for your advice, thanks!
comments.author: greg-ha-1990

comments.comment:
We use the SSDP protocol for device discovery, and I know HA already supports SSDP-based auto-discovery, but I still prefer to put it inside leviosa_shades instead of reusing the public SSDP discovery functionality because I want to customize the presentation of the device discovery page in a way that can help users understand the difference between different leviosa shades, and I don't want to scatter discovered leviosa shades in a massive list of chanting HA auto-discovered devices; in fact, I'll even hit the `ignore all` button，And sometimes the public device discovery function cannot complete all device discovery well.

Can I keep it in my own integration?

comments.comment:
Hi, thank you very much!

At first, we don't accept PRs which directly communicate with an API inside the integration. Please create a python package for the API communication and publish it on PyPI.

Secondly, it seems like you are scraping a web page to get data, which is not allowed. Maybe you can elaborate a bit on how fetching the data works.
comments.author: mayberryjp

comments.comment:
> Hi, thank you very much!
> 
> At first, we don't accept PRs which directly communicate with an API inside the integration. Please create a python package for the API communication and publish it on PyPI.
> 
> Secondly, it seems like you are scraping a web page to get data, which is not allowed. Maybe you can elaborate a bit on how fetching the data works.


The data is exposed by an APi but the authentication and schema is a bit unique. 

The schema is like a CSV but using ~ as a comma and | as new line character. So i am just transforming it into a KVP. 

To get the API you have to first auth and second get a CRSF token. The only bit of screen scraping is getting the token. 

The token can be reused across a long lifetime, but it only allows one concurrent user, so if someone else was to log in then that session token gets expired. So i go through the auth process every time. Its a local device so it is extremely fast even though its three HTTPS calls. 

I think of it different than screen scraping because in the end it is an API and the device is owned by the user and it's in their home and under their control to update and operate. It feels different than hitting some public website owned by a third party to retrieve stock quotes or weather or something like that. 

I will work on the documentation and the pypi part
comments.author: mayberryjp

comments.comment: Hello. I have moved the API code to pypi and I've tested the code successfully in my dev environment. The remaining thing I have to do is a PR for the documentation update. Is there any other feedback on the code?

> Can you maybe give some more context on what this code is doing and what kind of purpose it serves? What kind of devices are you connecting with this integration?

to get data from the API and register a new entity on HA the integration needs 4 informations, login data, Device Chip Id, Device port and Sensor on that port, so the config flow follow the steps: Ask for Login data, authenticate it through the API, gets device/chipids associated with that login data, show them in menu form for the user to select, stores the selected option in a configflow variable by clicking on one of the optionN menuoption, lists the available ports in that device (usually 4) and stores the selected port, then gets from the API the sensors on that DeviceChipid and that Port, lists them and stores it the same way as the Device and Port.

I have updated this to support HA `2024.4.0`. For everyone who is manually pulling this component in, don't update the component until you are running HA 2024.4 otherwise it won't work. If you have updated to 2024.4 you will need to update this component as well.

The tests are now running in the CI as well, which is great. The current `Split tests for full run` failure is unrelated to this PR

comments.comment:
I made quite a few changes to a local version trying to clean up the flow and startup.  It's still not perfect, and I'm not sure i like how I've set the devices up with "current" values rather than "stored" values, but I think you may find it helpful:
https://github.com/mkmer/HomeAssistant_Core/tree/ble-Husq/homeassistant/components/husqvarna_automower_ble
Pay close attention to the `__init__.py` execution order - there is a specific order to starting the coordinator to make sure data is available when the entities start up.

> comments are addressed

What about this comment though: https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/108326#discussion_r1599248788, users should not have to reload the integration to make it work. What happens if the automower is out of bluetooth range?
comments.author: alistair23

comments.comment:
> > comments are addressed
> 
> What about this comment though: [#108326 (comment)](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/108326#discussion_r1599248788), users should not have to reload the integration to make it work. What happens if the automower is out of bluetooth range?

I don't think it's possible to configure the integration if the automower is out of range (it won't / can't be discovered).  
I believe we fixed the issue when it's already configured and out of range at startup, it automatically retries by raising `ConfigEntryNotReady`.

Something flaky goes on when setting up and paring the device the first time.
1)  I paired and the setup "hung" at the pairing state.
2) Reloaded the integration and it found entities but they were unavailable.
3) Reloaded again and the entities became available.

On a second try with the esphome ble gateway already "paired" I still needed to do a reload to get the entities to become available when adding the integration.

comments.comment: I don't think we want to "fail" the integration here.  We have already "validated" the connectivity in the config flow.  At this point, it's just not in range and should continue to try.  Simply `raise  ConfigEntryNotReady()` to let HA retry automatically.

comments.comment: To answer @joostlek 's question, I followed [this part of the documentation](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/integration_fetching_data#separate-polling-for-each-individual-entity). Each device has its own api endpoint so it seemed to make sense to implement it this way.

comments.comment: How do you mean an API endpoint?
comments.author: crevetor

comments.comment:
Basically, each devices data is available at `https://api_base/<device_unique_id>/data` which seems to match this sentence in the documentation :

>  If you can map exactly one device endpoint to a single entity, you can fetch the data for this entity inside the update()/async_update() methods
comments.author: crevetor

comments.comment: Yes, but that sentence doesn't explain that it should be 1 config entry. I think that would be beneficial. Otherwise with stuff like reauth, you'd have to enter your credentials for every device.

comments.comment:
I wouldn't use an assertion here. What if some BLEDevice becomes available shortly after async_setup_entry is called? Then it will only become available once HA restarts again. 

You can also register a callback with HA in your async_setup_entry that will update the ble_device for your dice. This is useful if your device becomes available through a different adapter or bluetooth proxy:
```python
from homeassistant.components.bluetooth import (
    BluetoothCallbackMatcher,
    BluetoothChange,
    BluetoothScanningMode,
    BluetoothServiceInfoBleak,
    async_ble_device_from_address,
    async_register_callback,
)
from homeassistant.core import callback
    @callback
    def async_update_ble_device(
        service_info: BluetoothServiceInfoBleak, change: BluetoothChange
    ) -> None:
        """Update the BLEDevice."""
        dice.update_ble_device(service_info.device, rssi=service_info.advertisement.rssi)

    async_register_callback(
        hass,
        async_update_ble_device,
        BluetoothCallbackMatcher(address=entry.data[CONF_ADDRESS]),
        BluetoothScanningMode.ACTIVE,
    )
```
comments.author: anton-ptashnik

comments.comment: please clarify what exactly, VERSION var ?
comments.author: anton-ptashnik

comments.comment: initially I used `assert not None` to fix type check failure - `async_ble_device_from_address` returns BLEDevice | None, while `BleakClient` first arg is BLEDevice|str. But yes I agree that in case `ble_device` is None then AssertionError will be raised and HA will skip connection retry. I've put that code snipped under try-catch too to make sure I wrap an exception with `ConfigEntryNotReady` if any
comments.author: anton-ptashnik

comments.comment:
Has to do with migration, see https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/config_entries_config_flow_handler/#config-entry-migration

I was told it can be removed since `VERSION = 1` is the default
comments.author: anton-ptashnik

comments.comment:
If you ever get a type check failure you can also use TYPE_CHECKING constant which will only execute the assertion for type checkers:
```python
from typing import TYPE_CHECKING
if TYPE_CHECKING:
    assert ble_device is not None
```

But in this case I think the best way to solve it is indeed to use `ConfigEntryNotReady`, then HA will automatically retry it later. I would still add the `async_register_callback()` though to always have access to the latest BLEDevice

DiceColorSensor, BatteryLevelSensor and DiceNumberSensor all have a `dice` class variable. Why don't you put it in BaseSensor? Then you can also remove the __init__ for each of these right?

And you can include the descriptions like below. Also small point but you write `async_add_entities(entries)` but you are really adding entities instead of entries, but that won't be a problem if you do it like this.
```python

        (DiceColorSensor, COLOR_SENSOR_DESCR),

    async_add_entities([entity_class(entity_description, device_info, device) for entity_class, entity_description in entities])
```

I would suggest just writing names out fully when they are not too long. Makes it much easier to understand what the function does when quickly reading through it. Same goes for a couple of other cases like using 'desc' for 'description', or 'devinfo' for 'device_info' which you already addressed. Difference in length is not too much but something like device_info or _handle_number_update is much clearer as opposed to devinfo or _handle_upd

```suggestion
    ) -> None:
```

comments.comment:
Related to the other suggestion about DeviceInfo, I would include it here in the BaseSensor and then pass the ConfigEntry to the constructor

```suggestion
class BaseSensor(SensorEntity):
    """Base for concrete sensors."""

    _attr_should_poll = False
    _attr_has_entity_name = True
    
    dice: godice.Dice

    def __init__(
        self, entity_description: SensorEntityDescription, entry: ConfigEntry, dice: godice.Dice
    ) -> None:
        """Set default values."""
        self.dice = dice
        self.entity_description = entity_description
        self._attr_device_info = DeviceInfo(
            identifiers={(DOMAIN, device_name)},
            name=entry.data[CONF_NAME],
            manufacturer="Particula",
            model="GoDice",
        ),
        self._attr_unique_id = (
            f"{device_info[const.CONF_NAME]}_{self.entity_description.key}"
        )
        self._attr_translation_key = entity_description.key
```

comments.comment: I don't think it is a good idea. Doing this way we don't learn from the checker but just make type checking pass while the checker watches but ignore its recommendations when it does not. I have been running the sbidy/wiz_light integration for a while and thought I would take this PR for a spin.
So I pulled sbidy/core and built myself a Docker image of the current wiz_light branch on top of *armv7-homeassistant-base:2021.01.0* which is now running in my home.

A couple of observations/thoughts:

## Missing label/explanation for host address input
![missing-field-description](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21171566/104247388-ff81e680-5467-11eb-8ba0-e5a746163608.png)

### Input validation error message 
If triggering an input validation error with a non-supported address, the *Name* field will reset.
This leads to users not just having to input the host address one more time, but their desired name as well.
![error-handling](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21171566/104247595-62737d80-5468-11eb-8eb5-d534e867cbe4.png)
Also, typo with the **enterd** IP.

### Limited to adding lights by IP through GUI
My router runs OpenWRT and will happily register and resolve DHCP client hostnames. This means that I don't have to worry about static DHCP address entries, and have defined my lights in the following manner from previously:
```yaml
light:
  - platform: wiz_light
    name: spisebord
    host: wiz_7395e0
```
Should it work the same way through the GUI as through configuration.yaml?

### Thumbs up
Thumbs up and thank you @sbidy for moving this forward :smile:

comments.comment:
I changed and updated the integration regarding some open PR in the lib and related integration.

Three points I will not change:
1. Re-use sockets: I think it makes not that big difference to open a UDP socket for each request, either to re-use an open one. Because the interaction with the bulb are (mostly) short and not defined for a longer interaction period. I will consider this in one of the next version of the lib. But for now there are bigger issues to solve.
2. YAML support will stay: Some users are using this feature to make bulk imports of bulb IPs. For interaction with the bulbs' no secretes are needed by design. There are no confidential data stored in the YAML file. It is not recommended using this YAML file, but this integration will support this until the feature will completely be removed and deprecated by HASS.  Note: The auto discovery of the bulbs are added, but this will not work in a container-ed environment because the bulb discovery will happen via UDP broadcast, which is not that easy to implement in a standard docker environment (`network_mode: host` etc.).
3. No changes to (newer) implementation guides: Sorry, but I don't want to change my code/PR every time the HASS dev guide was updated. I'm waiting since the beginning of this year for a fundamental feedback to the integration. Now I wait for a workflow approval to test the code. Obviously there are multiple HASS users out there which are waiting for this interaction. And yes the integration is not 100% aligned with the (moving) development requirements of HASS BUT most of the existing and new ones are also not that "good". Yes there are "broad exceptions" ... But my major issue from https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/44779#issuecomment-934151485 was not resolved jet. And I'm not sure, but this can be an issue between the HASS update engine and the interaction .... but I can't resolve that issue ......

Thanks...

**EDIT:** Sorry for my harsh and not that correct words. I'm looking forward to make this integration ready for release soon. Thank you @bdraco and ... sorry 😞
comments.author: sbidy

comments.comment: Second opinion request is for https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/44779#issuecomment-950344177
comments.author: sbidy

comments.comment:
While not being a core member I can tell you something to some of your points from past experience.

>  I changed and updated the integration regarding some open PR in the lib and related integration.
> 
>  Three points I will not change:
 
> Re-use sockets: I think it makes not that big difference to open a UDP socket for each request, either to re-use an open one. Because the interaction with the bulb are (mostly) short and not defined for a longer interaction period. I will consider this in one of the next version of the lib. But for now there are bigger issues to solve.
> YAML support will stay: Some users are using this feature to make bulk imports of bulb IPs. For interaction with the bulbs' no secretes are needed by design. There are no confidential data stored in the YAML file. It is not recommended using this YAML file, but this integration will support this until the feature will completely be removed and deprecated by HASS.

The architecture decision is from 2020, as seen here: https://github.com/home-assistant/architecture/blob/master/adr/0010-integration-configuration.md#decision

I've also stumble upon this a couple times in the past when submitting code, it's also documented here: https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/configuration_yaml_index

From a user perspective and in alignment to the ADR I'd say that it's much easier for a user to set up an IP/Host directly in the UI than manually going in the configuration YAML.

> Note: The auto discovery of the bulbs are added, but this will not work in a container-ed environment because the bulb discovery will happen via UDP broadcast, which is not that easy to implement in a standard docker environment (network_mode: host etc.).

I'm not sure what discovery type wiz uses, but you are free to provide the user with default data in the config flow that you can for example provide via a multicast request (it works with network_mode: host). We are also using this for our GatewayScanner in the KNX integration.

If wiz supports any of the HA discovery modes you can implement them directly in the config flow for an even better user experience: https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/network_discovery/.

> No changes to (newer) implementation guides: Sorry, but I don't want to change my code/PR every time the HASS dev guide was updated. 

Most of the review comments you received where about things that are already documented in the HA dev guide for a long time (i.e. the YAML config deprecation). Technology evolves, and this in turn means the dev guides might get adjusted. The work is not done when new integrations are merged, there is maintenance and feature additions as well. 

> I'm waiting since the beginning of this year for a fundamental feedback to the integration. Now I wait for a workflow approval to test the code. Obviously there are multiple HASS users out there which are waiting for this interaction.

There are a lot of PRs open as you can see, it takes time. Especially for bigger ones.

> And yes the integration is not 100% aligned with the (moving) development requirements of HASS BUT most of the existing and new ones are also not that "good". Yes there are "broad exceptions" ... 

Well I can tell you from past experience that it will not get merged until it meets those requirements and that is good. After all, those requirements are there for a very good reason.

> But my major issue from Introduce wiz_light integration for WiZ bulbs #44779 (comment) was not resolved jet. And I'm not sure, but this can be an issue between the HASS update engine and the interaction .... but I can't resolve that issue ......

I personally can't help you with that problem as I don't own a wiz bulb and thus can't properly test and analyse it, but there are maybe some people in the HA discord that can help you with your problem.

> Thanks...

Thank you!

comments.comment:
Hello @Sotolotl,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`c5c2cf143881e8a8521137343e09230edf744cf6`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/44929/commits/c5c2cf143881e8a8521137343e09230edf744cf6) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (git@billystevenson.co.uk). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:
comments.author: Sotolotl

comments.comment:
I am not sure if this is allowed, since you don't specify all properties yourselves. Are you sure it only contains [valid device properties](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/device_registry_index/#device-properties)? Best would be to do it as the example below, where you can always pull the info from `self.dev_info`.

```python3
   return {
            "identifiers": {
                # Serial numbers are unique identifiers within a specific domain
                (hue.DOMAIN, self.unique_id)
            },
            "name": self.name,
            "manufacturer": self.light.manufacturername,
            "model": self.light.productname,
            "sw_version": self.light.swversion,
            "via_device": (hue.DOMAIN, self.api.bridgeid),
        }
```
See https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/device_registry_index/#device-properties
comments.author: mduran80

comments.comment:

comments.comment:
@frenck HI thanks for the reminder. I'm quite busy currently, but I will try to fix this. But after over one year to get this integration into Home-Assistant I'm questioning if this PR is the correct way.

Neato and Vorwerk Vacuum cleaners are both based on `pybotvac` and act the same way. The only difference is the authentication flow.
My idea was to just copy the neato integration and fix the authentication flow. But after all the reviews it's a whole new integration that has nothing to do with the neato anymore. 

Please don't get me wrong all review findings were correct and the code is better now. But now it is no longer a fork of the neato integration. It is more a recode of it and that was not my intention when I started this PR.

Maybe it is a better idea to add the Vorwerk-Auth0 authentication to the neato integration. @dshokouhi and @Santober what do you think about this idea? Could you help me?

The ConfigFlow in this PR works for over one year now and I also have a working `pybotvac` patch, where the `PasswordlessSession` is based on the `OAuthSession`, that should work with Home Assistant like the neato `OAuthSession`. 

What I'm not familiar with is the Home Assistant oauth2 token handling. Who could help me with that part?

comments.comment:
`python_rako` seems to be almost strictly typed. To make it fully strictly typed you need to add `disallow_incomplete_defs` to mypy config.

If you export typing information by adding `py.typed` marker, then you can probably make this integration to pass strict typing checks. 

For this add it `.strict-typing` file in the repo root.

comments.author: marengaz

comments.comment:
You can only get merge conflicts here on common files like `.coveragerc` or `CODEOWNERS`. But they should be pretty simple to resolve.

Typical workflow:
```shell
git fetch upstream
git rebase upstream/dev
```
In case of merge conflict, fix files and:
```shell
git add fixed_file.py
git rebase --continue
```
And `git push --force` in the end.

comments.comment: Use key references where possible.
comments.author: marengaz

comments.comment: hey @milanmeu - so i see people [using keys like this](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/f516650ab7c1e900cd437b845a2fc04b09d6e217/homeassistant/components/hue/strings.json#L13), but its black magic to me. could you point me to a list of available keys / documentation about how it works?
comments.author: marengaz

comments.comment:
It is recommended to use [key references](https://docs.lokalise.com/en/articles/1400528-key-referencing) so that we only have to translate common words once in [Lokalise](https://lokalise.com/signup/130246255a974bd3b5e8a1.51616605/all/).
Developers docs: https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/translations#translation-placeholders

### Common keys
The `common` keys list: [homeassistant/strings.json](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/dev/homeassistant/strings.json)
These have the following format: `[%key:common::JSON-PATH::JSON-PATH::THE-KEY%]`
Example:
`[%key:common::config_flow::data::port%]` will be converted to the value from [homeassistant/strings.json](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/dev/homeassistant/strings.json): `Port`.


### Component keys
It is also possible to make a reference to a key in [homeassistant/components/rako/strings.json](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/45915/files/f516650ab7c1e900cd437b845a2fc04b09d6e217#diff-12b41571ac481723939fddc1f22894804eab5959adcaa7c4f56c5c2432fc8099).
These have the following format: `[%key:component::rako::JSON-PATH::JSON-PATH::key%]`
Example: 
`[%key:component::rako::config::step::user::description%]` will be converted to `If pre-populated, Bridge was auto-discovered!`

### More information
It is possible to combine references with strings. Example:
`[%key:common::config_flow::data::name%] (Optional)` becomes `Name (Optional)`

It is possible to combine references with references. Example:
`[%key:common::config_flow::data::host%]:[%key:common::config_flow::data::port%]` becomes `Host:Port` 

It is not allowed to make a reference to a reference. (https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/46999)
It is not allowed to make a component reference to another integration.

### Suggestion

- `Port` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::data::port%]` (Port)

Choose what fits best or don't use a reference if none fits:
- `Host IP` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::data::host%]` (Host)
- `Host IP` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::data::ip%]` (IP Address)
- `Host IP` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::data::host%] or [%key:common::config_flow::data::ip%]` (Host or IP Address)

This changes "bridge" to "device". If bridge fits better then no reference can be used.
- `No bridge found on the network` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::abort::no_devices_found%]` (No device found on the network)

Choose what fits best or don't use a reference if none fits:
- `Cannot connect to the Bridge` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::error::cannot_connect%]` (Failed to connect)
- `Cannot connect to the Bridge` -> `[%key:common::config_flow::error::cannot_connect%]` (Failed to connect to the Bridge)
comments.author: marengaz

comments.comment:
@stefano055415 something went wrong with your merge / rebase, can you try to fix that?

A simple way to recover can be the following flow:
- Update `dev` on your local fork to match upstream
- Rename your local `freedompro` branch to `freedompro_old`
- Create and checkout a new `freedompro` branch off `dev`
- Cherry-pick the relevant commits from `freedompro_old` tp `freedompro`
- Force-push the `freedompro` branch, this PR will then point to the new `freedompro` branch

For the future, this is a good guide for a simple workflow which will always work: https://gist.github.com/Chaser324/ce0505fbed06b947d962

comments.comment:
@stefano055415 Now it does indeed look fine again 👍

Just a question, should the light work in "optimistic" mode or not?
Optimistic means Home Assistant assumes an attempt to turn on or off the light was successful, and should mainly be used in cases where the device or service doesn't push updates and where it's also not possible to request a state update.

It's preferred to not use optimistic mode when not necessary.

Optimistic:
```py
    async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        self._attr_is_on = False
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
```

Non optimistic:
```py
    async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
        await self.coordinator.async_request_refresh()
```
comments.author: stefano055415

comments.comment:
I think there has been some confusion, even I would prefer to use the non-optimistic version.

From:
```py
async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        self._attr_is_on = False
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
```

To:
```py
 async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
        await self.coordinator.async_request_refresh()
```

and 

From:

```py
async def async_turn_on(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set on to light."""
        self._attr_is_on = True
        payload = {"on": True}
        if ATTR_BRIGHTNESS in kwargs:
            self._attr_brightness = kwargs[ATTR_BRIGHTNESS]
            payload["brightness"] = round(self._attr_brightness / 255 * 100)
        if ATTR_HS_COLOR in kwargs:
            self._attr_hs_color = kwargs[ATTR_HS_COLOR]
            payload["saturation"] = round(self._attr_hs_color[1])
            payload["hue"] = round(self._attr_hs_color[0])
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
```

To:

```py
async def async_turn_on(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set on to light."""
        payload = {"on": True}
        if ATTR_BRIGHTNESS in kwargs:
            payload["brightness"] = round(kwargs[ATTR_BRIGHTNESS] / 255 * 100)
        if ATTR_HS_COLOR in kwargs:
            payload["saturation"] = round(kwargs[ATTR_HS_COLOR][1])
            payload["hue"] = round(kwargs[ATTR_HS_COLOR][0])
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
        await self.coordinator.async_request_refresh()
```
comments.author: stefano055415

comments.comment: @DevSecNinja There is still an issue with sold coins, their sensors become unavailable, once value becomes 0, we should create a balance/asset dict where users can choose to follow assets (like the markets), even if balance is 0, and/or add a dynamic enable toggle, so people can choose for dynamic behavior, where sensors are removed if balance has become 0 or added for new assets >0 balance.
comments.author: DevSecNinja

comments.comment:
> @DevSecNinja There is still an issue with sold coins, their sensors become unavailable, once value becomes 0, we should create a balance/asset dict where users can choose to follow assets (like the markets), even if balance is 0, and/or add a dynamic enable toggle, so people can choose for dynamic behavior, where sensors are removed if balance has become 0 or added for new assets >0 balance.

Well in most cases some value (e.g. 0,00001) is left behind after purchase as Binance will round the amount of coins you purchase. In the past I allowed a selector with Bittrex on #44618, but I removed it as it won't create new sensors for new coins. A dynamic enable toggle would be nice indeed.

comments.comment:
Hello @Sholofly,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`b335418de9f5bf6a09c37c5ede796cd17d5a2bc2`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/50284/commits/b335418de9f5bf6a09c37c5ede796cd17d5a2bc2) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (rudolf.offereins@netivity.nl). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment: Thanks @frenck!
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment: Is it too late to migrate in the review to migrate `GeocachingSensorSettings` to `EntityDescription`?
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> Is it too late to migrate in the review to migrate `GeocachingSensorSettings` to `EntityDescription`?

Can't find anything about EntityDescription on the developers site. Can you elaborate on this?
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> > Is it too late to migrate in the review to migrate `GeocachingSensorSettings` to `EntityDescription`?
> 
> Can't find anything about EntityDescription on the developers site. Can you elaborate on this?

There is no documentation available yet, but you can take a look at all these PRs to give you an idea:
https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pulls?q=is%3Apr+entitydescription+in%3Atitle

Basically you assign `self.entity_description` to your sensor class, and you no longer need to set the `_attr_` attributes.

This is how it works internally for icons:
https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/37219e8d04485666a98c74e9a6b7efe29a612662/homeassistant/helpers/entity.py#L355-L362
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> I don't think the diagnostic category makes sense for most sensors that where disabled before. It hasn't to do with diagnostics at all. Except, maybe, for the username.

It is to mark them secondary (that is what it entails for this case). I agree the term diagnostic is a bit weird maybe.

The alternative is to make them hidden by default (which makes them show up on the service page, but not on the default dashboards).

Or to not mark them at all, but that makes them all primary... which is also not right I think?
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> I don't think the diagnostic category makes sense for most sensors that where disabled before. It hasn't to do with diagnostics at all. Except, maybe, for the username. But regarding the categorization I personally don't see the difference between the total_finds sensor and the total_hides sensor, for example. So then you should make them all diagnostic or none of them? What are your opinions about this @frenck, @reinder83 ?

Yeah I agree that diagnostic is weird here
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> > I don't think the diagnostic category makes sense for most sensors that where disabled before. It hasn't to do with diagnostics at all. Except, maybe, for the username.
> 
> It to mark them secondary (that is what it entails for this case). I agree the term diagnostic is a bit weird maybe.
> 
> The alternative is to make them hidden by default (which makes them show up on the service page, but not on the default dashboards).

Yeah they can be hidden by default, except for total finds, and maybe the souvernirs? the other only make sense if you also hide caches
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> I personally don't see the difference between the total_finds sensor and the total_hides

The reasoning for me was: Total hides is not something that would/should show up on the default / auto-generated dashboard by default. Mainly because it depends if you hide caches, and if you do, that would not be something that changes a lot / adds values to a default dashboard.
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> It to mark them secondary (that is what it entails for this case). I agree the term diagnostic is a bit weird maybe.

Yeah that's why we made them hidden by default. But, as you stated, that has disadvantages too. Is there a integration where a comparable choice is made? In that case I can agree with it.
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
> Yeah that's why we made them hidden by default.

No, they originally were disabled by default :) But that was created before we had entity categories and the hidden feature.
comments.author: Sholofly

comments.comment:
Pushed out an alternative

- User stays diagnostic
- Souvenirs is now a primary entity as suggested by @reinder83 
- Other previously diagnostic entities are now marked as hidden by default

Hidden entities still show up on the device/service page (as in my last screenshot), are active and can be automated on, but are not shown on generated dashboards.

Please let me know if this matches more with what you guys envisioned.

comments.comment:
> Some checks were not successful ...

Ah...
I developed on Fedora 34 which depends (comes with) Python 3.9.
legrand_rflc requires pypi lc7001 1.0.1 which depends on this version (3.9).
That's why it breaks under 3.8.

It turns out that legrand_rflc and pypi lc7001 do work with Python 3.8 (even though the rest of Fedora isn't happy).
I updated the requirements to call for pypi lc7001 new version 1.0.2 (which now calls for Python >= 3.8).
See new commit.
https://github.com/rtyle/home-assistant.core/commit/bede64893d8c379cc57dc16f709d4f9ee4f33476

Can we please try again?
comments.author: rtyle

So, I do have a problem with this integration. Reason: We already have a Legrand integration.

Why is this a separate integration? Isn't that majorly confusing for end-users? They just want to use their Legrand stuff, right?

Both will support (light/)switches... how do they know which one to choose?
Can we merge them? Should we even allow for two?

comments.comment:
> So, I do have a problem with this integration. Reason: We already have a Legrand integration.

Yes, I assume that you are talking about the Legrand Home+ Control (home_plus_control) integration.

> Why is this a separate integration? Isn't that majorly confusing for end-users? They just want to use their Legrand stuff, right?

Yes, it confused me too. These are two different, incompatible, ecosystems. They each were derived from different sources (acquisitions).

> Both will support (light/)switches... how do they know which one to choose? Can we merge them? Should we even allow for two?

Both support light switches in their own, mutually incompatible, ecosystem. I can't speak for home_plus_control, but as for legrand rflc please see https://www.legrand.us/solutions/smart-lighting/radio-frequency-lighting-controls

comments.comment: If the protocols and ecosystems are wildly different and incompatible, then I feel like the best thing we can do is have really good documentation in both integrations that mention this and explain what the user has to deal with.  IE, It's not our fault the vendor did something crazy here, and trying to build one frankenstien integration that handles both just because of naming seems difficult to maintain?
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
> IE, It's not our fault the vendor did something crazy here

Well lets not mimic their mistakes 😩 

Another option is to do merge it in a single domain and guide the user in the configuration flow, that way, we don't burden our users with the faults/bad decisions of a manufacturer.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
> Another option is to do merge it in a single domain and guide the user in the configuration flow, that way, we don't burden our users with the faults/bad decisions of a manufacturer.

A merge is a bad idea. These are completely different things. Also, one (that) is cloud based while the other (this) is Local Push.

In my submitted documentation, I have clearly said what this **is**.
```
The Legrand RF Lighting Control integration allows you to control and monitor the lights connected to your Legrand|On-Q LC7001 Whole House Lighting Controller.
```
There are many things that it **is not**.

Just like any core Home Assistant integration, I think a user should be able to assume that this is not like any other integration or why else would it be here.

Legrand is the make. RFLC is the model. Home+ Control is another Legrand model. Saying that RFLC is not Home+ Control is like saying a Corvette is not a Camaro.
I have no problem saying it but it just seems silly.

comments.comment:
I think the code **will** be easier to maintain as 2 integrations with a clear separation of concerns.

You have a valid UI concern but it looks like a UI concern driving a backend decision. We just need some extra UI to help the user pick the right integration.  That doesn't mean 2 unrelated codebases have to live in the same integration, that is actually a limitation of the current UI for setting up an integration.

Such a UI would be really useful and could handle other variations of this concern such as if we wanted to let the user choose between using the native integration for an thermostat (quite a few of these are cloud and polling based) or using the homekit API (which is local and push based, and doesn't require the user to get a developer API key).
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
> I think the code will be easier to maintain as 2 integrations with a clear separation of concerns.

Nothing is stopping a developer from creating separate packages inside the integration package.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
Is there an example of that now? What is the best practice on how to setup an integration consisting of multiple unrelated sub integrations. Presumably there is a boilerplate file for each platform to import from the sub-integrations. Should there be a boilerplate setup function in each platform that calls each sub integration to create its entities? Or a single setup function per platform and you just put the entities in separate modules. How can you break up a config flow into multiple modules? It's currently a single class per flow isn't it?

It also breaks some of our developer flows as the developers of the sub integrations might be unrelated, they don't want to be codeowners of each other's sub integration. 

And this is all assuming the integration picker is a worse place to have the user choose that the config flow. I don't think it is in this case.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
> Is there an example of that now? 

Sure, Nest for example.

All the rest of your questions depend on the integration being built. We don't limit that.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
It looks like this concept of a sub-integration is not a first class concept in HA. Maybe it should be formalised, maybe doing so would rid it of the boilerplate?

The Nest one is kinda ok because the entities are somewhat related and it's somewhat transitionary rather than completely unrelated, but there is a lot of boilerplate here.

So I stand by my opinion here, though I know it's not worth much to you. Right now, this is a boilerplate heavy workaround to use configflows to make up for a UI deficit. I think it's a Ui concern driving a backend decision.

And as you don't I'll go away now 😃
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
> It looks like this concept of a sub-integration is not a first class concept in HA. Maybe it should be formalised, maybe doing so would rid it of the boilerplate?

This is not the place for such discussions. I don't think 2 integration warrants for such architectural discussions either.

> I think it's a Ui concern driving a backend decision.

Incorrect, it is an end-user-driven comment. A user wants to integrate their Hue bulb. Not their specific type of Hue bulb. This is nothing different, an user isn't aware of these differences. We can guide them.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
Different Hue bulb types share an ecosystem. This is more like Hue vs. Dynalite which are both by Philips (except they are compatible to a degree). 

Home+Connect and RFLigtingControl don't - they only share a manufacturer. But have different logos, mobile apps, connection method, library requirements ... I think an owner is able to differentiate.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
Look, I've know i've said it twice but let me say it again, I don't disagree with your UI concern. We can and should definitely make a nice user experience wherever possible. I just have concerns about the details of this implementation approach. The "nitty gritty". They come from a place of love and wanting the best outcome for everyone.

One thing I like about your idea is that it could potentially probe a device and pick the right sub integration automatically. E.g. by seeing which ports are open. I don't think that is the case in *this* particular case because Home Control and Legrand RFLC are so different (local vs cloud), you have to make a decision to login or to enter an IP before we can do anything clever?

I think there are potentially lots of small paper cuts with it (exactly because there are (currently) only 2 integrations in this situation) (But there are more, btw - e.g. Honeywell):

* I was initially concerned with boilerplate. I hoped if we had an architecture conversation about your idea someone cleverer than either of us would suggest some way to have HA core load the subintegration directly and avoid nearly all the boilerplate.
* One immediately obvious concrete example of a paper cut is one of your own code cleanups - #49865. It's only a small detail, but RFLC is a local connection class. The other is cloud. You can't have both in a single manifest. If we have a single integration made of subintegrations, `iot_class` cannot be a property of the manifest. I guess this means even in the core team we still have some confusion about what an integration is?
* This idea will dilute/confuse the meanings of the `codeowner`, `requirements` and `quality_scale` keys too.  I don't think @rtyle really wants to end up answering bug reports about `home_plus_control`. And @rtyle thinks this code is platinum grade, where as the existing legrand integration doesn't offer any quality level.

As I said above, in this particular case I don't think we can automatically pick the right integration. The user needs to know whether to login to the cloud system or enter a host and password. It seems like we should be able to guide them to make the right choice from the "add integration" UI without invoking a config flow first.
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
> I don't think @rtyle really wants to end up answering bug reports about `home_plus_control`

Certainly not. I am a HA developer newbie making an honest effort to contribute and play by the rules. That is hard enough but now, it seems, the rules are changing under my feet. All of this is making my head spin.

Legrand is a huge company with **many** brands
https://www.legrand.us/Brands
Many of these brands are based on acquisitions of companies of the same name.
Products and technologies that have grown from these different sources are still supported and growing under the Legrand brands.

Of interest here are Wattstopper, On-Q and Netatmo.

Wattstopper (acquired in the 90s) owns the trademark for the Topdog RF communications layer (not z-wave or zigbee) which is used by RFLC. On-Q (acquired in the 00s) is responsible for the ethernet/IP gateway (lc7001 hub) used by RFLC. Their API allows local access.

Netatmo (acquisition started in 2018) uses the Zigbee protocol and requires a different  Wi-Fi gateway. Their API accesses devices indirectly through the cloud.

Legrand considers the products we are discussing as separate, independent systems at the same smart-lighting level.
RF Lighting Control
https://www.legrand.us/solutions/smart-lighting/radio-frequency-lighting-controls
Smart Lighting with Netatmo 
https://www.legrand.us/solutions/smart-lighting/with-netatmo

Basically, the only thing that these product lines have in common is the Legrand logo on the box.
If/when Legrand swallows up Leviton, that shouldn't imply that the existing/different HA integrations for Leviton need to be swallowed up under a single Legrand integration.

I am frustrated. I don't know what to do. I don't know how this process works, who the players are and what weight their voice carries. I have seen @frenck on HA youtube videos. Does his disapproval sink this ship?
comments.author: rtyle

comments.comment:
So a service can be a internet connection at a premises, or a mobile phone collection.

Each "service" requires a unique API call to retrieve its data, so instead of assuming the user wants the integration to poll for data from every single service they are given the choice at setup, and using configure.

As it does require extra requests, I believe it meets the requirements of that Architecture decision.

comments.comment:
Hi,
integration works perfect. Just two questions:
1. I saw that power1-3 are disabled by default, but I see no possibility in the device-config to enable them (I don't have them listed). Is this the intended behaviour?
2. I have a sensor called "Total Production", which shows - since the beginning - 0,2021001 kWh. What is the meaning of this sensor? (btw I don't produce energy)

Nevertheless,
Thanks for this integration and crossing fingers, that it will soon become official.


Joerg
comments.author: jpbede

comments.comment:
@derjoerg thanks for testing. 

> 1. I saw that power1-3 are disabled by default, but I see no possibility in the device-config to enable them (I don't have them listed). Is this the intended behaviour?

You should have an option called "+3 hidden entities" under the sensors, if you click on it, it will expand and you will see the 3 disabled entities. If you click on one of it, it will open a modal with additional settings where you can enable it.

![CleanShot 2022-04-07 at 11 30 08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3989428/162168310-2d9c8c63-e841-43cd-a274-f751f1d9142b.png)

> 2. I have a sensor called "Total Production", which shows - since the beginning - 0,2021001 kWh. What is the meaning of this sensor? (btw I don't produce energy)

Discovergy usually installs a 2-way meter suitable for solar production. Since I cannot distinguish whether you are producing energy or not when the  integration gets activated, the total production sensor is activated by default. You can deactivate it in the same way as you activate a sensor.
comments.author: jpbede

comments.comment:
For integrations that connect to devices or services, we no longer accept new YAML configuration.

This integration needs to be refactored first to use a configuration flow and config entries first.

More information about this can be found in Architecture Decision Record:

- ADR-0010: <https://github.com/home-assistant/architecture/blob/master/adr/0010-integration-configuration.md#decision>

See our developer documentation on how to get started creating a configuration flow for this integration:

<https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/config_entries_config_flow_handler>

From a user point of view, it would be interesting if Home assistant would be able to have access to the full P1 meter parameter list, instead of only the limited list this custom component currently offers.
The full parameters are accessible by using the P1-meter API, that delivers the complete telegram, containing all measurements and data the digital meter is capable of.
http://{IP address}/api/v1/telegram
comments.author: DCSBL

comments.comment: I would love that, but it would mean that this component needs to parse data from the P1 differently than the other Energy devices (JSON vs raw telegram) which is a bit of a hassle. The support for all entities exposed by JSON is currently in the pipeline by HomeWizard so I think it is not worth it to use the raw telegram data.

comments.comment:
Thanks for the review @farmio 

PH changes quite often but not drastically if we check the 2nd decimal point (e.g. 7.21 to 7.22) as electrolysis is a chemical process that naturally raises PH, and this kind of chlorinators have a peristaltic pump that liberates PH reductor in the flow to counter that effect.

I left the 30 seconds interval because it's the default. Coincidentally I sniffed packages in my local network using wireshark to check how often the chlorinator sends updates to the platform and it's around 30 seconds too (unless there's user interaction, in which case it does immediately). I can make it a minute if that's a concern.

However what can change quickly is the state of the binary inputs and relays of the chlorinator, which I removed from this initial PR to comply with the "one platform per pull-request" policy, but as soon as this one is merged I'll open more PRs adding other platforms.

Considering other platforms will be added, maybe 30s is not too much.

The link to my library was correct but I forgot the repo was private. I made it public now.

See note at: https://docs.aiohttp.org/en/stable/client_quickstart.html#make-a-request

This change is not a requirement for this PR, so you can change this in this or another PR.

comments.comment:
Have you considered not using `DiscoveryService` at all and directly implementing `Listener` here?  It seems like the code can get simpler by inlining some of these calls and just implementing `Listener` in each place you want to listen to an event.

For example, my impression is that `Listener.controller_discovered` is invoked on the first time you add a `Listener`, this you don't need to both loop over the existing found controllers.

This then becomes something like this:
```
async def async_setup_entry(...):
    class InitListener:
        def controller_discovered(self, ctrl: Controller) -> None:
            async_add_entities([ControllerDevice(ctrl)])

  pi_disco = hass.data[PI_DISCO]
  pi_disco.add_listener(InitListener())

```
comments.author: lazdavila

comments.comment:
My impression from reading the pescea library is that the `Controller` itself knows about the state change, then it has to notify the `DiscoveryService` which then invokes the `DiscoveryService` in home assistant, which then fires an event that notifies the `ControllerDevice` which compares back with the original `Controller`.

You might find this gets simpler to avoid the global dispatch by having a listener on the `Controller` itself, rather than via the discovery services and notifications. That way a `ControllerDevice` could call `add_listener` on the `Controller` and have fewer comparisons to make.

It also seems like you could also get away with a single event, for what its worth, and just checking the current state of to determine if `_attr_available` needs updating. Having multiple callbacks still results in 3 very similar looking callback methods.

I realize the existing integration this is modeled after does this, but its not clear to me its necessary so i thought i'd suggest these ideas for simplifying further.
comments.author: lazdavila

comments.comment:
The most common way this handled seems to be to do all the setup in `async_setup_entry` and tear down in `async_unload_entry` only.  To me this seems more straight forward than having these method methods that store state in `hass.data` which are called from a few places.  I think [gree](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/c68b259bd3e43d77fe9b9d47c768f9aa6198571e/homeassistant/components/gree/__init__.py#L26) is a good example.

As an example, unload happens both from the home assistant stop event and from unloading the config entry and it just makes it a little harder to reason about.

The downside of this is that the config entry and the setup entry do not share the same discovery services, but i think thats ok since config flows are a fairly rare event.  (gree also has a nice interface for initial device discovery in the config flow as well with its `scan` which is nice too fwiw)
comments.author: lazdavila

comments.comment: I incorporated @bdraco 's suggestions and added an extra verification to determine that the correct connection was made. I changed the way entities are registered. Previously it would register all possible entities and disable the ones that are not usable. Now I only register usable entities. This makes the end-user experience better because the user's screen isn't populated with 18 different entities when most likely they would only use 6 of them.
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment:
- Incorporated @bdraco 's suggestions.
- Increased poll time from 10 (default) to 30 seconds. I felt like 10 seconds is too fast to poll the state, and if user makes a change to a zone in home assistant, the amp state is updated immediately.
- Set default zone names. If this was not done, user would not be able to select zones until user configured it through an options flow.
- Disable polling and set device state to unavailable if amplifier turns off at anytime. This is to prevent logs from filling with error messages, and to save on resources.
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment: Incorporated @bdraco suggestions.
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment:
Added coordinator to retrieve data and update my entities. I call `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)` when a service is called (such as "set volume") to tell HA to pull data from the WS66i amp in order to update my states. However, sometimes there is a big delay between when `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)` is called and when data is pulled, so there are times where there is a big delay from when the user changes a state to when lovelace updates the state. It seems like HA is throttling my calls to `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)`. Unfortunately this makes for a bad user experience.

I still need to test shutting off my amp while integration is active...

Edit: Maybe I can bypass the coordinator and have my entity update its own state and alert HA that state was changed. This way I can avoid the long delays with `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)`.
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment:
I am confident that commands sent off to the WS66i amp will be accepted, so my entity class will update its state and alert HA by calling `self.async_write_ha_state()`. This will provide immediate feedback to the end-user, and won't poll the amp each time the user makes a change through HA.

Since pyws66i returns a ZoneStatus class, my entities will reference that instead of copying those values locally. This means I brought back some `@property` attributes as they will need to read from the ZoneStatus class.

I've added coordinator handling to close the WS66i connection if the data pipeline breaks (such as the amp powered off) and on subsequent coordinator updates, it will retry to establish a connection.

I made the fields in the options flow required. If the user were to not provide a value in a config flow, that user would not be able to select a source through HA. This is undesired and required additional error checking in a few other places. This is especially problematic if the user selected a source via the keypad that wasn't configured in the config flow. By making them mandatory, the user has the freedom to select all available sources and some error checking was no longer needed, simplifying code.
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment: I tried making the restore service more robust by remembering what the snapshot status was between HA restarts, however the data in `hass.data` is wiped out between restarts. Is there any place to store data persistently for integrations?
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment:
> I tried making the restore service more robust by remembering what the snapshot status was between HA restarts, however the data in `hass.data` is wiped out between restarts. Is there any place to store data persistently for integrations?

 I suggest removing the services for now and working through them in a followup PR. 

https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/creating_component_code_review?_highlight=small&_highlight=pos#5-make-your-pull-request-as-small-as-possible
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment:
Sorry, I was getting ahead of myself. I was trying to continue to make improvements during a PR and that just makes it more difficult for you, the reviewer.

About custom services, these services should stay however; they are vital components to the integration. A basic automation will, for example, listen for an event, such as a doorbell rang event, snapshot the zones, play a notification indicating someone is at the door, and then restore the zones. In this use case, the snapshot will no longer be needed because a new snapshot will be taken whenever a notification needs to be played. Come to think of it, snapshots don't need to be in non-volatile memory at all.

I won't be making any more changes. In a future PR, I'll look into discovery. I hope this is acceptable.
comments.author: ssaenger

comments.comment:
So it's been over 2 months since I submitted this...
Can anyone review this please? @MartinHjelmare @frenck @bdraco @balloob @fabaff
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
That can happen, please do not ping for reviews, especially since well, some people celebrate Christmas with their families now as well.

In general, don't ping for reviews.

Thanks 👍
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
> That can happen, please do not ping for reviews, especially since well, some people celebrate Christmas with their families now as well.
> 
> In general, don't ping for reviews.
> 
> Thanks 👍

First of all I do understand it's Christmas right now and I don't expect an immediate review. You can tell that since I've waited over two months without pinging anyone.
Please, don't use such a convenient excuse for not reviewing something when there's proof all over HA that some contributions take insane amounts of time to be reviewed... Specially since well, you're using the fact that it's Christams to make me the bad guy here and that's not fair...

Anyway, I'll wait without pinging anyone or eventually close this since apparently only contributions made by the core members of this project are reviewed/merged in a reasonable time, as opposed to contributions made by third parties, which  can be delayed forever if none reviews them...
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
That is true, core contributors are often faster reviewed. This is normal. 

Pinging (and thus slightly demanding) reviews, is not accepted. This is not an excuse; but policy. Please respect that. 

Contributing is not just opening PR, is it also reviewing. Feel free to help out doing that so the queue becomes smaller. Looking forward for you to help out.

PS: Me personally skips PRs that ask for reviews, because I don't want it to work like that.
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
> That is true, core contributors are often faster reviewed. This is normal.
> 
> Pinging (and thus slightly demanding) reviews, is not accepted. This is not an excuse; but policy. Please respect that.
> 
> Contributing is not just opening PR, is it also reviewing. Feel free to help out doing that so the queue becomes smaller. Looking forward for you to help out.
> 
> PS: Me personally skips PRs that ask for reviews, because I don't want it to work like that.

@frenck It would be great to dedicate more free time to help in Home Assistant if I didn't have more open sources projects to contribute to such as OpenWrt or Linux. However, my free time is scarce because my main work isn't related to Open Source projects and for other personal reasons.
I was just stating that this project has a problem that needs to be solved as I've done before. If you don't want to see that and not review someone which is stating a problem that's fine, you're just harming third parties which might be interested in having this integration.
I suggest you change your mind about this.
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
I am sorry? I suggest you adjust your above statement as it becomes personal. That is not accepted and violates our CoC.

Please consider this a warning.
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
> I am sorry? I suggest you adjust your above statement as it becomes personal. That is not accepted and violates our CoC.
> 
> Please consider this a warning.

I removed the part which I assume you're taking as personal and leaved the rest. If you're taking anything else in that statement as personal please quote it, since I don't think it's violating any CoC now, but I could be wrong.
Yes, I admit I can be wrong sometimes. People should also do that more often :).

Anyway, as I already said I suggest you guys should take actions so that it doesn't take months to have a simple review because I love this project, but as any other project it has issues, and some of them need to be corrected as soon as possible...

Also, I'm not considering this as a warning, but as me trying to make you guys change your mind about your way of handling problems with this wonderful project.
comments.author: Noltari

comments.comment:
Thank you for adjusting the comment 👍 

> Anyway, as I already said I suggest you guys should take actions so that it doesn't take months to have a simple review because I love this project

There isn't much action to take. We can't force people to help out doing review. People in general simply like to submit PRs (which is great as well, but doesn't reduce the review queue).

In the end, we can't dictate what people should do here; We don't control any contributions (no matter what type of contribution is made).
comments.author: Noltari
