comments.comment:
Hello @mtarjoianu,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`879bf45c464dd5462943d2580bd9127a48d02c80`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/60413/commits/879bf45c464dd5462943d2580bd9127a48d02c80) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (mihaela.tarjoianu@scada.ro). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:
comments.author: mtarjoianu

If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting "Author Name" and "`email@address.com`" for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

Hello @mtarjoianu,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:


- [`9db6dd1a6a97dc535978201e70cdafef27020ec9`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/60413/commits/9db6dd1a6a97dc535978201e70cdafef27020ec9) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (mihaela.tarjoianu@scada.ro). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.


Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

comments.comment:
@frenck The issue is that the integration is used for monitoring 3d printing, as such it's not really possible to deliver only a single platform and the integration be considered useful. The sensors included represent a minimal subset that are common in monitoring setups.

I can break it up if there is no other option, but it will be somewhat unfortunate as it will mean many many months before the integration has any practical use for users.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

comments.comment:
I think you got the description mostly correct.

async_unload_entry will be called of you ask to reload or disable a config entry. It should first ask all platforms (cover, switch, ...) to unload (which will remove all entites, calling the will remove callback on all entities registered on that config entry and platform). Once that is complete, the integration async_unload_entry will (should) continue to disconnect any connections and remnant state of the integration.

It should be done in this order to avoid any entities being dependent on unloaded global state/connections.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment:
> Why can't a hostname be used?

Because the device tells me only the IP address. See also the [Remootio Websocket API documentation](https://github.com/remootio/remootio-api-documentation), e.g. the [newest version (v3)](https://github.com/remootio/remootio-api-documentation/blob/master/websocket_api_v3_specification.md) of it.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment:
> This overwrite any required field invalid errors from above.

This is intentional, because the device can also be discovered using zeroconf, but this will be implemented in a later version of the integration.

If the device is discovered using zeroconf, only the IP address is known first, the other data (API Secret Key and API Auth Key) must be given by the user. The idea was that in this case only the error message _Please complete the setup of your Remootio device._ with key `user_input_incomplete` would be presented to the user.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment:
> Don't abreviate. Write it out in full.

The constant `CONF_API_SECRET_KEY` is used in the voluptuous schema based on which the form for configuring the integration is presented to the user. When I write it out in full, a password field for the _API Secret Key_ is displayed on the form, but a simple text field for the _API Auth Key_, which I didn't want.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment:
> you should set up the connection in the **init**.py file. Otherwise it will end up harder to add other entity types.

I implemented this because, according to the [documentation](https://github.com/remootio/remootio-api-documentation/blob/master/websocket_api_v3_specification.md), the device automatically closes an unauthenticated session after 30 seconds.

In the method `utils.create_client` an instance of the `RemootioClient` class is instantiated, whereby a connection to the device is also established and, among other things, the authentication takes place. - The library [_aioremootio_](https://pypi.org/project/aioremootio/), which contains the class `RemootioClient`, was also written by me.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment:
> This should really be converted to DataUpdateCoordinator. With CoordinatorEntity entities. This will schedule there own update once the coordinator updates.

I don't understand why I should use a DataUpdateCoordinator here?

After a time that can be configured via the Remootio app, the device triggers a `LEFT_OPEN` event if the controlled garage door or garden gate has been left open. This event is received by the `RemootioClient` and calls the listener `RemootioCoverEventListener` for it, which in turn triggers a `remootio_left_open` Home Assistant event.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment: I use this method both in the method `utils.get_serial_number` and the method `utils.create_client` to translate exceptions of the library into Home Assistant exceptions.
comments.author: ivgg-me

comments.comment: The error `UnsupportedRemootioApiVersionError` is an exception of the integration raised by the method `utils._check_api_version`, the `RemootioClient` can throw some other exceptions from the library (which also contains the `RemootioClient`) that I handle in the method `utils._handle_exception`.

comments.comment: A hostname for any IP address can be set on your DNS server/router. Advanced users might want to do that to keep control of their systems.

comments.comment:
Hi,

The way dates are returned by the API is not always consistent. I did apply a fix for this in version 0.7.1 of the underlying python package to communicate with the API but did not upgrade the integration to use this updated version.
As a temporary fix, simply change the `requirements_all.txt` file to use `gps-tracker==0.7.1` instead of `gps-tracker==0.7.0` and hopefully it will do the trick.

I will push the fix on this PR this evening when I'll be at home.

Thanks for this report!

Hi,
To use an integration as a custom_component, you must add a `version` item in `manifest.json`, I guess you forgot that step?
Otherwise, I have no idea...

You may also take a look to https://github.com/timothyle97/Invoxia-HA : @timothyle97 converted this pull request into a custom_component that you may directly copy into your home-assistant instance. See [here](https://github.com/timothyle97/Invoxia-HA/blob/main/custom_components/invoxia/manifest.json#L13) in particular if you need an example for the `manifest.json` tweaking.

Unfortunately, I have lost hope about this PR being accepted one day so using a custom component might be the best approach...

comments.comment:
Thanks for you implementation, i tried it already as custom component.

But it looks like not every value is working for me :-(
But not a problem with your implementation, my varta station didn't send the value :-(
Really missing the total production power.
Any idea?

But for the rest it works! Thanks a lot!!

![Screenshot_2022-02-09-16-15-01-007_com android chrome](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14292633/153258311-e27b41da-2ece-4c25-b91c-a18be98ed6b2.jpg)
comments.author: Vip0r

comments.comment:
> Thanks for you implementation, i tried it already as custom component.
> 
> But it looks like not every value is working for me :-( But not a problem with your implementation, my varta station didn't send the value :-( Really missing the total production power. Any idea?
> 
> But for the rest it works! Thanks a lot!!
> 

You can't imagine how excited i am. You are the first one using this integration. That feels marvelous :)

Regarding your question: While implementing the modbus client for the API i found two different docs describing the Modbus registers, formats and so one (just let me know and drop me a msg if you wan't me to share it with you) 
In the documentation i saw that some Modbus registers are only available for different device types. (This means some register are only available for VARTA element, some for VARTA pulse, some for VARTA link and so one)
Sadly i also found the documentation is not fully correct. For example i found some some file types are in the reality on my device different from the documentation and so one.
Long story short, there is unfortunately nothing you can do. I have on my side the same situation, the device is providing only the current production power of my panels and not the total one.

One thing you should check: When browsing on to the WebUI of your VARTA device, check if you configured your inverter connection in the settings (Energymanager => SunSpec-Manager)

Last but not least you will have the following option. After configuring your inverter-connection as described above you should see at least the current production power for your panels in HA,  you can use the the core integration "Rieman sum integral" (https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/integration/) to generate a total value (per day/per week/..) for this

Hope this helps you. Just let me know if you have any further questions
comments.author: Vip0r

comments.comment:
Hi!
Happy to see your integration! I have some trouble with calculating total charge/discharge energy with the riemann integration (if interested: [[Riemann integration for discharge and loading behave different](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/riemann-integration-for-discharge-and-loading-behave-different/393003)](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/riemann-integration-for-discharge-and-loading-behave-different/393003)

Because of this I would be interested how you get on this values. I see you have values for total discharge and charge. As far as I know there is only a modbus register for the total charge energy (1069 lower / 1070 higher word on my Varta Element).
comments.author: Vip0r

comments.comment:
> Because of this I would be interested how you get on this values. I see you have values for total discharge and charge. As far as I know there is only a modbus register for the total charge energy (1069 lower / 1070 higher word on my Varta Element).

Hey, as you mentioned total charged energy is: 1069 lower / 1070 higher word.
For discharge the VARTA element only provide the current values:
- active power in W (1066, SINT16)
- apparent power in VA (1067, SINT16)

comments.comment:
If you are using the [development environment](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/development_environment) as advised, you can [manually trigger](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/development_testing#testing-outside-of-tox) the tests for your integration with

```bash
pytest ./tests/components/vartastorage/ --cov=homeassistant.components.vartastorage --cov-report term-missing -vv
```

The requirement will be fullfiled when you get as an answer

```
----------- coverage: platform linux, python 3.9.9-final-0 -----------
Name                                                   Stmts   Miss  Cover   Missing
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
homeassistant/components/vartastorage/config_flow.py       XX      0   100%
homeassistant/components/vartastorage/const.py            XX      0   100%
homeassistant/components/vartastorage/sensor.py          XX      XX     0%
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TOTAL  
```

In the `test_config_flow.py`, you will find many `patch` context such as

```python3
    with patch(
        "homeassistant.components.vartastorage.config_flow.PlaceholderHub.authenticate",
        side_effect=CannotConnect,
    ):
        result2 = await hass.config_entries.flow.async_configure(
            result["flow_id"],
            {
                "host": "1.1.1.1",
                "username": "test-username",
                "password": "test-password",
            },
        )
```

the `patch` context lets you change the output or behaviour of one function durint the execution of the context. You can use this to force your `hub.test_connection()` to raise `CannotConnect` and thus confirm that your `config_flow.py` does raise this error in case of connection error.
Similarly, the `test_form` method must check that the config_flow works correctly if everything goes well during the entry_setup.

In your case, you can completely drop the `test_form_invalid_auth` as there is no authentication involved in your entry (and thus you can remove 
```python
        except InvalidAuth:
            errors["base"] = "invalid_auth"
```
and the `InvalidAuth` class from `config_flow.py`
)

I hope this helps you!

comments.comment:
Hello @al-s,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`a3ec34d0533836cbc129cea93741b840614b8bc9`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/66130/commits/a3ec34d0533836cbc129cea93741b840614b8bc9) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (alexs@pushok.com). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

comments.comment: Not sure about this. The [docs](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/network_discovery/#mdnszeroconf) say that we should add `zeroconf` to `dependencies` if we use `async_get_async_instance`. Perhaps with the `zeroconf` section, this dependency is added implicitly, but I have not found this documented in any way. However, I have noticed that most integrations specify it in `after_dependencies` (i.e. as an optional dependency), and this is more appropriate since having mDNS functionality is not an absolute requirement.

Fix the problem with the switch jumping back and forth

return to the new state.

I highly suggest to setup development environment as I mentioned here https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/66431#issuecomment-1044210871 with a development environment setup besides integration tests everything is run on pre-commit so you don't need to do any manual step.
Basically with development environment all you need to do is:
1. Run integration tests (by selecting a pre-defined task for that)
2. Commit the changes - this runs pre-commit if pre-commit changes files, check the changes and stage them if thy are ok

comments.comment:
> Great to see all the hard work on this integration! Will it be ready for the upcoming release? Is the “day lock” feature part of the integration? Would be nice to be able to add that to some HA automations.

What do you mean by "Day lock" feature? This integration provides a [lock](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/lock/) entity that by default allows the actions "Lock" and "Unlock". If you wish to open the door from home assistant you can use the `lock.open` service.
comments.author: cpolhout

comments.comment:
> > Great to see all the hard work on this integration! Will it be ready for the upcoming release? Is the “day lock” feature part of the integration? Would be nice to be able to add that to some HA automations.
> 
> What do you mean by "Day lock" feature? This integration provides a [lock](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/lock/) entity that by default allows the actions "Lock" and "Unlock". If you wish to open the door from home assistant you can use the `lock.open` service.

Sorry I meant “Open House Mode”. Would be nice to be able to call a service from HA to turn on or off “Open House Mode”.
comments.author: cpolhout

comments.comment:
> ...
> Sorry I meant “Open House Mode”. Would be nice to be able to call a service from HA to turn on or off “Open House Mode”.

This will not be possible in the initial release. To keep the PR as small as possible only 1 platform (the lock itself) is added. Once this gets merged we can continue to add functionality such as changing the lock's settings.
comments.author: cpolhout

comments.comment:
@tonysprenk :
> I meant “Open House Mode”. Would be nice to be able to call a service from HA to turn on or off “Open House Mode”.

The [Loqed web API](https://support.loqed.com/en/articles/6127911-loqed-web-api-integration) does not support **changing** the "open house mode", nor does it trigger a webhook call when it is enabled/disabled in the Loqed app.

It is only possible to **see** the current status of open house mode, when manually requesting the status using the web API (**not** when using the local bridge API): `guest_access_mode` has value 0 or 1.

Why are we storing entry data here?

It might be better to create/initialize the client library at this point and store that instead.

It also allows for error handling at this point. If there is an error with e.g., connecting to the device the entry setup can be aborted (and retried later by Home Assistant).

comments.comment:
Its a bit tricky.

in order to get the MAC of the CU, I must login to it first, if the user provides the same credentials, it'll momentarily break the token of the other session, this will result of error  message in the log and a reconnect attempt will happen on the next state refresh (meaning the already configured device).

And it doesn't promise a successful login every time because of the already configured device session running and trying to take over repeatedly.

comments.comment:
Hello @osohotwateriot,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:


- [`f37e1d82bcd90e3439864dc64574c2f4a28bdbcb`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/70365/commits/f37e1d82bcd90e3439864dc64574c2f4a28bdbcb) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (marian.graurov@icbdigital.no). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.


Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting "Author Name" and "`email@address.com`" for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

comments.comment:
@davet2001 I've been in contact with @DasBasti as we've both been working on an integration for Sungrow inverters in parallel. As he was further ahead with the integration itself and the process of getting it reviewed and merged while my backing library was more advanced we decided to work together already as part of this PR, since it was not yet merged. As such I have modified Bastians code to use my library.

A review of these changes would be greatly appreciated!
comments.author: DasBasti

comments.comment:
It looks like you have rebased and force pushed.

I can't easily see what has changed since I last reviewed and I would prefer not to re-read all >1000 lines.  

Please could you describe what you changed?
comments.author: DasBasti

comments.comment:
@davet2001 Thanks for taking the time!

Here is a diff of just the changes to this integration I've made: https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282
Note that it excludes changes in generated files like requirements and CODEOWNERS, as those also include changes from other commits so are harder for me to isolate.

The file with the most significant changes is [`__init__.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L1-L284), as my library is async (although not 100% until HA switches to pymodbus 3 but that has to wait for upstream and the modbus integration) I had to move some stuff out of the SungrowData constructor into `async_setup_entry`. It also contains some aspects in `SungrowCoordinatorEntity` previously found in `sensor.py`, which is mostly just a preparation for more entity types (which I've got ready locally but will be part of a future PR).

[`config_flow.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L285-L368) should be functionally equivalent.

[`const.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L369-L588) lost the sensor definitions, I moved them into `sensor.py`, again as it makes more sense to me once more entity types are there.

[`sensor.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L608-L1075) gained the sensor definitions, quite a few more as my library supports more, while also losing some details in them (like device class and unit) that I instead compute inside of `SungrowCoordinatorEntity` based on the metadata in `pysungrow`.

In the tests the changes are almost exclusively about changing what is mocked, I did however introduce a [fixture](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L1207-L1231) that takes care of the patching that is done for most tests, as well as creating and registering the config entry.

Other than that it's of course quite a few import changes, as well as some adaptions to changes in the HA API, like using `SensorDeviceClass` instead of strings and going from `async_setup_platforms` to `async_forward_entry_setups`.
comments.author: DasBasti

comments.comment:
> I have a Dremel 3D printer so I will have to try this. For easier review, we ask that only one platform is in the initial PR. 100% test coverage is also required for `config_flow`. Thanks for your contribution!

@tkdrob It would be awesome if you could test it on your Dremel 3D Printer! Even more awesome if you hold the versions 3D20 or 3D40, which don't have camera, to see if the API works the same way as it does on the 3D45 model and it adds the same entities as it does for the 3D45 model except the Camera. Otherwise, having another pair of eyes testing it on the 3D45 model would be appreciated as well. Please let me know how that goes.

I've added the test coverage to `config_flow`, and left only the `Sensor` platform, as requested. Should I also remove the services added by this PR?

By the way, if you don't mind me asking, I've looked into the documentation but couldn't find directions on how to align this PR with the changes to __1.__ add documentation to Home Assistant docs and __2.__ add a logo for this integration on the Integrations UI. Can you link me to the documentation on how to do so or simply guide me on how can I make progress on that? I understand there are two different repos for docs and for logo respectively, but I'm lost as to how can I align PRs made to those repos with this PR, so that they are published together, or in other words, what's the correct order of repos that I should make changes to (adding docs first, then adding logo, then publishing this diff? Publishing this diff first? etc.)

Also, after this PR gets accepted, should I keep adding the other platforms to this same PR and asking for a new revision or open a new one?

comments.comment:
Hello @cibernox,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`ab3f74e6e96fa46b7a2fadb7d39f67f6f52dc85f`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/72982/commits/ab3f74e6e96fa46b7a2fadb7d39f67f6f52dc85f) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (miguel_camba@apple.com). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.
- [`f94ed3da51d634e9f091930081a1ef3e2dd239fb`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/72982/commits/f94ed3da51d634e9f091930081a1ef3e2dd239fb) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (miguel_camba@apple.com). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

comments.comment:
You might want to disable wind speed and wind direction by default as they are updated 20 times per minute. The wind average and wind direction average are updated once per minute like the other sensors.

*Edit: corrected typo*
comments.author: jeeftor

comments.comment:
> You might want to disable wind speed and wind direction by default as they are updated 20 times per second. The wind average and wind direction average are updated once per minute like the other sensors.

It's actually around 20 times per minute (every 3 seconds). While still frequent, I would argue that it's one of the more relevant sensors.
comments.author: jeeftor

comments.comment:
> It's actually around 20 times per minute (every 3 seconds). While still frequent, I would argue that it's one of the more relevant sensors.

Oops, typo. Corrected. Thanks for catching. But it's still a valid question as those two sensors accounted for around half of all data in my HA database.
comments.author: jeeftor

comments.comment:
> > It's actually around 20 times per minute (every 3 seconds). While still frequent, I would argue that it's one of the more relevant sensors.
> 
> Oops, typo. Corrected. Thanks for catching. But it's still a valid question as those two sensors accounted for around half of all data in my HA database.

Yeah, agreed. Wind direction for me is less relevant. But wind speed is crucial. Sometimes a minute delay is too long and can cause serious damage. I get frequent wind which can spike very quickly. Being able to react to the first such spike is important as a full minute of sustained high winds can be disastrous. I guess the question is, should it be disabled by default with a note saying to enable it if you need it. Or should it be enabled by default with a note saying it may cause a large HA database and disable if unneeded?
comments.author: jeeftor

comments.comment:
> But wind speed is crucial. Sometimes a minute delay is too long and can cause serious damage. I get frequent wind which can spike very quickly. Being able to react to the first such spike is important as a full minute of sustained high winds can be disastrous.

It would be nice to be able to use the data for automations without being stored. Or maybe have a different retention period.
comments.author: jeeftor

comments.comment:
> It would be nice to be able to use the data for automations without being stored. Or maybe have a different retention period.

True. The immediate value is wonderful for automations. After that, I only really care about the statistics of it and don't need the rest of the granularity.

comments.comment:
> It would be nice to be able to use the data for automations without being stored. Or maybe have a different retention period.

I found that it's possible to prevent recording selected values. This leaves them available to use for automations.

```
# https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/recorder/
recorder:
  exclude:
    entity_globs:
      - sensor.outdoor_wind_speed
      - sensor.outdoor_wind_direction
```

comments.comment:
I guess it could be, however, the most common case is that an individual will have a **single** weatherflow device in their house which is sending out **UDP** packets on the local network. Being that its **UDP** we don't need to actually know the IP address of the Weatherflow device and we will be using a value of  `0.0.0.0` for `CONF_HOST` which is actually better described as a host filter rather than a specific host we are getting data from ... and in this case just saying `Weatherflow` I believe is clearer than `Weatherflow 0.0.0.0`

We have two options:
- UPD Traffic from a single specific IP
- UPD traffic from anywhere (this is a much easier setup case because if your weatherflow device changes DHCP it will still wokr)

comments.comment:
Let's take air temp as example.
Let's say the device sends the information as 70 F and you have configured the sensor to be natively using F as unit.
Then HA will convert it for a metric user by itself to 21 C.
Now you're doing all kind of conversions to do that for the user when it should not be needed (HA will take care + the user can always change after).

Or can the device send different depending on the setting so you assume it's configured same as their HA? Can we then check that instead?
comments.author: jeeftor

comments.comment:
So internally the backing library is using the pint class which has a ton of internal conversions: https://pint.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user/nonmult.html Some of the sensor values are coming in in "non-ha-supported" units in some cases. We aren't actually ALWAYS doing the conversion. In the case of any Temp sensors, however, we are not applying ANY conversion ... (as I hope to show) ```python @dataclass class WeatherFlowTemperatureSensorEntityDescription(WeatherFlowSensorEntityDescription): """Describes a WeatherFlow temperature sensor entity description.""" def __post_init__(self) -> None: """Post initialisation processing.""" self.native_unit_of_measurement = UnitOfTemperature.CELSIUS self.device_class = SensorDeviceClass.TEMPERATURE self.state_class = SensorStateClass.MEASUREMENT self.decimals = 1 ``` This will just pull in the native `c` value off the sensor. I've rewritten the code a little bit to maybe make it more clearer. So when we are in `def native_value(self) -> datetime | StateType:` ```python # Extract raw sensor data raw_sensor_data = getattr( self.device, self.entity_description.key if self.entity_description.attr is None else self.entity_description.attr, ) ``` We get a Quantity & units value. ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/33de67fa-6487-4737-ab20-749de391f49b) Temperature sensors utilize HA conversion -> so it doesn't jump into the conversion block at all. ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/2b4c6bfe-ed35-479b-927a-52f070a02045) In the next block it will just extract the sensor value and round it accordingly: ```python if isinstance(noramlized_sensor_data, Quantity): sensor_value = noramlized_sensor_data.magnitude if (decimals := self.entity_description.decimals) is not None: sensor_value = round(sensor_value, decimals) return sensor_value ``` So it's just skipping over the logic (even though it is called) - and then all we are doing is parsing out the `sensor_value` and applying a rounding factor.
The few cases it does need to apply conversions is when its using Non-hA supported units in say `Air_Density` Home Assistant natively doesn't support the values in question: ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/d706d987-7101-4069-af4f-8f08a998dbf6) So for this value ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/d84c290f-98e6-4415-99f4-298516a1becb) There is a conversion function which is applied - the native HA ones won't cut it ... (I made a few rewrites after writing this to update variable names for clarity) ... happy to remove them and go back to the simpler version if you prefer but hopefully this explains some of the logic better. In summary: -> We don't really have to do this that often, but sometimes its needed on the sensors... It still takes advantage of the Native HA conversion when possible (like the temp example) where it will store the value in native in C allowing HA to handle the F conversion

I've just gave it another go. The good news is: I can login now 👍  The bad news is, there are no updates coming through. 😞 

I have the Aqara M2 hub connected to my Aqara account, with multiple devices. In this case, I tested with a Aqara motion sensor and a door/window sensor. Both devices show up in Home Assistant as expected.


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/195327/196247885-2af5f60b-8762-48a7-88e9-0698054490e6.png)

Their initial state on startup is correct and matches the device. But after the initial, the state is never updated again. The state of the contact sensor and the motion sensor both show up in the Aqara app (when opening/closing the contact sensor or when motion is detected). But nothing happens in Home Assistant. The state in Home Assistant won't change when opening/closing the contact sensor or when motion is detected.

![CleanShot 2022-10-17 at 19 57 24](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/195327/196249021-59191a41-c2ed-4703-85a2-d76d6bea3909.png)

I've tried to set some breakpoints to detect if data is coming in, but I don't see anything; nothing is triggering.

comments.author: Rudd-O

comments.comment:
there are a couple of options you can do:
1. the most straightforward is to think of some initial, limited functionality in the first PR, then add the additional ones in future PRs. Surely, there is a partial usage that will already give some, although not all, of the value. This will likely reduce your config_flow and other hass parts that will be deferred to the next PRs. Once you have the framework with minimum functionality, adding the additional ones will require smaller PRs that will get faster reviews
2. If the absolute MVP still requires a large amount of code, they have options to set a side branch, which can have multiple PRs. Each one can be small and implement a part, and it will only be released when you feel it is ready.

When I released the Dynalite integration, initially it only had lights, which is very limited. Switches, blinds, and other functionality was added in later PRs. When working on the first one, I learned some of their coding standards and built a good alignment with the reviewer, so the future ones were much quicker.

comments.comment:
The thing is, this code (casting certs and keys from bytes to objects) is _only_ needed because HASS insists on storing strings / bytes -- the integration only deals in actual typed Python objects, like `Certificate` and `Key`.  Short of moving these casting functions into helpers within the client, this actually belongs here and not in the MPRIS client.  All of the logic of actually obtaining the certificate and pairing with the remote end is fully sealed up in the MPRIS client.

What should I do?  I'm 100% new to writing HASS code, I need your help.  Thanks in advance.
comments.author: Rudd-O

comments.comment:
While we want to store configuration data in the config entry, certificates are a bit large to put in there since everything has to be serialized to JSON and back.  Config entry storage isn't a database so every time its loaded/saved all the data for all the config entries has to be processed.

You can storage large data in `.storage`

You can accomplish this in two different ways.

You can pass the storage path to the library with `hass.config.path`. `git grep` for a few examples in the code base, and let it be responsible for reading the certificates from disk (in the executor please!)

Also you can use `homeassistant.helpers.storage` to store the certificates.  There is an example in `homekit` for aid storage.

I almost always prefer the solution that has the least code in HA itself and offloads that to the PyPI package code since it reduces the review time to make changes to an integration and keeps things moving along.
comments.author: Rudd-O

comments.comment: Roger that.  The client module has no provision to store anything on disk -- it is stateless -- so I will factor out the certificate load / save code to their own separate functions and proceed as you advised with regards to mirroring what `homekit` does.

comments.comment: It would be best to set `self._attr_unique_id` at this point with [a unique ID](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/entity_registry_index/), as that makes it a lot easier to manage the entity. I don't immediately see anything unique that could be used, other than the config entry's id, so that would probably be your best bet.

comments.comment:
The API seems to be very easy-going in its matching, so I can imagine people getting a different station they expected from time to time if the first result is always chosen. Maybe only take the first result if there's only one matching station, or when if the search query matches the first result 100%? And in other cases list like the first x matching stations in the error message.

In theory, you could also provide HA with a list of stations to limit the results only to valid options, but I suspect that might be a bit too much to handle in the UI.

comments.comment:
Ready for review once again.

---

I've been using a fake device to test the integration: https://github.com/cottsay/aioraven/blob/main/test/mock_device.py

You can set up the device using socat: `sudo socat -d -d pty,raw,echo=0,link=/dev/ttyACM0 "system:python3 test/mock_device.py,pipes"`

It doesn't set the appropriate PID/VID for USB discovery to work, but you can manually add the integration. It was pretty useful for ensuring that the error handling in the integration works as expected.

comments.comment:
This yields the same string but using a different underlying data type. The function operates on `ListPortInfo` but this code utilizes a `UsbServiceInfo` instance. The field names are the same except the UID/GID, which is stored as a number in the former and a string in the latter.

IMO, designing the a function to deal with both data types would result in more code to do the same task.

comments.comment:
```suggestion
class RAVEnSensor(CoordinatorEntity[RAVEnDataCoordinator], SensorEntity):
```

For new integrations, we require the following:
- Support for [the new entity naming](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/core/entity#has_entity_name-true-mandatory-for-new-integrations)
- Services must be [translatable](https://developers.home-assistant.io/blog/2023/07/11/translating-services)
- Entities and their attributes should be [translatable](https://developers.home-assistant.io/blog/2023/03/27/entity_name_translations/)

Please adopt your code to add support for it.

comments.comment: I moved the synchronization logic into the library. I'm not sure I agree that the rest of this code should go there. It's opening the device, getting the list of programmed meters, and getting the type of each of those meters. These are all discrete operations and I don't see much value in lumping them together in the third-party library and breaking the one-to-one relationship between library queries and device messages.

comments.comment:
The library should raise an specific error for these exceptions. These exceptions are implementation details and they should be transparent for the caller.

In our [developers docs](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/api_lib_index) we have written the following:

> One of the foundational rules of Home Assistant is that we do not include any protocol specific code. Instead, this code should be put into a standalone Python library and published to PyPI.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting "Author Name" and "`email@address.com`" for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

first start at porting existing utility-like plugin to work with electric kiwi

basic balance sensor for Electric Kiwi

add in logger and a few other possibly required imports

pinning dependencies and adding integration type

Fix copy/paste documentation errors

Add in auth2 flow and make updates to various flows

fix a few PR issues raised with duplicate consts and an import and an issue with basic auth

Add unique id and fix issue with initial call for connection id and customer number

Use NAME const and remove commented out code and consts

Move scope values to const

Tests pass for auth flow

Sort out tests, owners, coverage and rebasing

change to production url

add in missing reauth strings

if somehow the token is valid but the request fails raise catch the error and re-auth on set active session

move to async forward entry setups as per warning

use correct account balance

make the entities easier to extend and add one more

Add a few more entities and correctly classify them into their classes

no need for private async update now

24 hours is a bit too long, every 6 hours seems more reasonable for keeping it up to date.

move to using data coordinator pattern

move the coordinator to its own file

add select and seperate sensor entity for the start time of HOP

update manifest with latest version of the API

add electric kiwi to the strict and mypy configs

add in end time and tidy up what unique id returns and bump version of api for model fixes

address the checklist and remove account balance over hop as hop is more useful

address mypy issues

address comments and a few more tidy ups, accidentally removed async entry so restored that too

remove homekit item from manifest

Co-authored-by: Franck Nijhof <frenck@frenck.nl>

remove unneeded items from manifest

comments.comment:
This implies the duration always has two digits, which sounds like an assumption that could break at any point.

Additionally, this will happily match e.g. `"६೬,"` because of two bugs:
* `\d` matches any decimal digit, not just the ASCII 0-9, by default. You can add the `re.ASCII` flag, or explicitly specify `[0-9]`. (The characters above are Devanagari and Kannada decimal digits.)
* You don't need commas in a character class.

I'd go with 
```suggestion
DURATION_PATTERN = re.compile(r"^[0-9]+[SMH]$")
```
and then maybe upper-case the duration string in `parse_duration`.

comments.comment:
> > The bluetooth is used for the device discovery and we're using the simplepyble module doesn't currently provide pre-built wheels for Linux ARM (e.g. Raspberry). In the future we may provide multiple optional bluetooth backends such as pybluez.
> 
> I'm afraid using another library this will conflict _hard_ with how Home Assistant does Bluetooth internally using `bleak`. If you want to use the HA internal Bluetooth bits (which do e.g. device discovery for you and automagically allow showing new matching devices as ready-to-set-up in the HA UI and so on), the `edilkamin` library should be agnostic as to how the data is sent or received to the device, but just parse it.
> 
> You might want to look at the other `_ble` integrations for inspiration (though many of them are sensor only, and I'm not sure how hooking up the active command bits would work; cc @bdraco on that...).
> 
> **EDIT:** if https://github.com/AndreMiras/edilkamin.py/blob/5e52900ef938391b8a59416da60516308cfdc7f1/edilkamin/api.py#L41-L59 is indeed the only thing the `edilkamin` library needs BLE for, it should maybe be an optional feature (pip extra) with a late import for the BLE library, so you could use the HA native Bluetooth discovery for MACs here, and people who want to build on `edilkamin` without HA could do e.g. `pip install edilkamin[ble]`. Please feel free to ping me if you need help with the pip extras bits :)

Hi, I’m using https://github.com/home-assistant/core/tree/dev/homeassistant/components/yalexs_ble to control my lock via Bluetooth and it is working pretty smooth
comments.author: AndreMiras

comments.comment:
Hi @akx,
Thanks a mil for the valuable feedback. I've tried to ping you on Discord (`Aarnink#1056`) by the way, but I don't know if you're active there.


> I'm afraid using another library this will conflict _hard_ with how Home Assistant does Bluetooth internally using `bleak`. If you want to use the HA internal Bluetooth bits (which do e.g. device discovery for you and automagically allow showing new matching devices as ready-to-set-up in the HA UI and so on), the `edilkamin` library should be agnostic as to how the data is sent or received to the device, but just parse it.

Good to know, I thought it might be the case indeed. I've refactored the code to leverage `async_discovered_service_info()` and use the edilkamin library to only parse the result.

> You might want to look at the other `_ble` integrations for inspiration (though many of them are sensor only, and I'm not sure how hooking up the active command bits would work; cc @bdraco on that...).

I did look a lot of that indeed, but had hard time finding a cloud based integration that was only using bluetooth for the initial device discovery like in my case.
Basically that device is driven from an API on the "cloud", but no endpoint would return the device "ID", that can only be extracted using the device bluetooth MAC at the moment.
So it might look like a bluetooth integration, but it's not.
In the future I may also reverse their bluetooth protocol and make a fully bluetooth alternative integration, but for now I'm using their cloud integration.

> https://github.com/AndreMiras/edilkamin.py/blob/5e52900ef938391b8a59416da60516308cfdc7f1/edilkamin/api.py#L41-L59 is indeed the only thing the `edilkamin` library needs BLE for, it should maybe be an optional feature (pip extra) with a late import for the BLE library, so you could use the HA native Bluetooth discovery for MACs here, and people who want to build on `edilkamin` without HA could do e.g. `pip install edilkamin[ble]`. Please feel free to ping me if you need help with the pip extras bits :)

Addressed in the last release:
https://github.com/AndreMiras/edilkamin.py/blob/1.1.0/setup.py#L36
comments.author: AndreMiras

comments.comment:
> Hi, I’m using https://github.com/home-assistant/core/tree/dev/homeassistant/components/yalexs_ble to control my lock via Bluetooth and it is working pretty smooth

Hi @shisva thanks for sharing.
This integration doesn't actually rely on bluetooth to control the device.
The device is connected to the cloud and you control them by calling a cloud API.
The bluetooth is only used for the initial discovery in order to know the ID of the device you're controlling

comments.commit_message:
Initial Edilkamin stove integration

This is a first iteration with a basic set of feature:
- turn on/off
- get/set target temperature
- get current temperature

- [ ] Dependency upgrade
- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New integration (thank you!)
- [ ] New feature (which adds functionality to an existing integration)
- [ ] Deprecation (breaking change to happen in the future)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix/feature causing existing functionality to break)
- [ ] Code quality improvements to existing code or addition of tests

The bluetooth is currently only used for device discovery.
The device is then driven from a cloud based API.
It seems like alternatively the device can also be driven fully from
bluetooth, but the underlying `edilkamin` Python library doesn't support
it yet.

- [x] The code change is tested and works locally.
- [x] Local tests pass. **Your PR cannot be merged unless tests pass**
- [x] There is no commented out code in this PR.
- [x] I have followed the [development checklist][dev-checklist]
- [x] The code has been formatted using Black (`black --fast homeassistant tests`)
- [x] Tests have been added to verify that the new code works.

If user exposed functionality or configuration variables are added/changed:

- [x] Documentation added/updated for [www.home-assistant.io][docs-repository]
  https://github.com/home-assistant/home-assistant.io/pull/25072

If the code communicates with devices, web services, or third-party tools:

- [x] The [manifest file][manifest-docs] has all fields filled out correctly.
      Updated and included derived files by running: `python3 -m script.hassfest`.
- [x] New or updated dependencies have been added to `requirements_all.txt`.
      Updated by running `python3 -m script.gen_requirements_all`.
- [ ] For the updated dependencies - a link to the changelog, or at minimum a diff between library versions is added to the PR description.
- [x] Untested files have been added to `.coveragerc`.

To help with the load of incoming pull requests:

- [ ] I have reviewed two other [open pull requests][prs] in this repository.

comments.comment:
I few other things I noticed:
- When there is solar as part of the installation the "net" energy (both the totals and the MTUs) can be negative.  Consequently, the state_class for the daily and mtd sensors cannot be TOTAL_INCREASING and must be TOTAL.
- In the _now values in the SensorEntityDescription you could use device_class=SensorDeviceClass.POWER
- POWER_WATT is deprecated (replaced with UnitOfPower.WATT)
- ENERGY_WATT_HOUR is deprecated (replaced with UnitOfEnergy.WATT_HOUR)

Will continue to test and review...
comments.author: rianadon

comments.comment: Naming Note:  In a system that has Solar, the .consumption() values are how much total energy used in the house/office/etc, not necessarily the amount "consumed" from the utility.  In this case, .energy(). is the amount consumed from (or returned to, if negative) the utility.  It may be less confusing to use stype of "Energy Usage" for "consumption" and "Energy Consumption" for "net".  Thoughts?

comments.comment: Hi @emontnemery. As I mentioned before I had held off implementing the state class for net meters because I was a bit confused how to proceed. Your comment helped clarify things, but I'm still facing an underlying problem caused by the Ted 6000 device resetting at inconsistent times. I had asked on the discord and got no response, so I figure I'll ask here. I've been running my changes with `last_reset` for a few weeks, and today I decided to create a statistics card for one for one of the net meters to check how they're working. This is what I got. Based on the form of the state measurement, the sum should be an ever-increasing line. However, it has jaggies because the time that the sensor resets is inconsistent. Sometimes it's at midnight, but other days it can be as far as five minutes behind. As comparison, here's a non-net energy value that uses the `total_increasing` state class. Notice how the line is straight. Is there any great way to handle the inconsistent reset times? And if not, I'm thinking that maybe I should not give these net entities a state class `measurement`. The Ted6000 also publishes historical data (for example what was the total net energy use 6 days ago). Perhaps I could use these to detect whether the day has rolled over, but it sounds like a lot of extra logic. Perhaps this is better left to a future PR? It would be great to get this work merged.
comments.author: rianadon

comments.comment:
> it has jaggies because the time that the sensor resets is inconsistent. Sometimes it's at midnight, but other days it can be as far as five minutes behind.

The problem is that you're trying to calculate the `last_reset` time based on the local time. That simply won't work, you need to either get the time from the API or detect that a new period has started and bump the last_reset only then.
An example of the former is if the API includes some meta data indicating for which date the reading is.

Let's chat on discord if the way forward is not clear, I'm emontnemery#6618 there
comments.author: rianadon

@property
def available(self) -> bool:
    """Return True if entity is available."""
    return super().available and self._radiator and self._radiator.hass_available
```

Hi @Vaskivskyi,

In general, the hass team avoids multiple integrations. (Difficult to maintain and support)

They will most likely ask you to rebase on the existing integration. I know it's effort but it's possible to make it work with both the HTTP API as well as SSL (for legacy devices - don't know if it's worth keeping for a hand full of old devices though.).

Just my 2c.

comments.comment:
Let me just make some consideration on this PR and all the others that involve AsusWRT integration on which I'm code owner.
Original AsusWRT integration have some issue with new Asus firmware / router, partially fixed with some improvement in original AioAsusWrt library based on telnet / ssh. Because with new firmware Asus released new API based on HTTP, new library based on new API  becomes available.

On May 2022 I created PR #71899 with the scope to extend the AsusWRT integration with the new HTTP protocol. This integration was ignored for many months by HA teams (I was thinking because it's to big), so I put that PR in draft and create the new PR #84152 with the scope to partially implement the previous one to give the ability to integrate new libraries in the original integration. In the meantime I also created a [custom integration](https://github.com/ollo69/ha_asuswrt_custom) that is a copy of the first PR and that I'm using from months without any issue.

Honestly I don't really like the idea to have 2 integrations for the same device, this will probably create a lot of confusion to the users. And the old integration cannot be simply removed, because old routers that do not implement HTTP API still need that version. 

But I really think that have new HTTP protocol available for new Asus routers is important, a well working device tracker is one of the most important part of Home Automation. So I hope that HA Teams will take one of this PRs in charge to better support one of te most used router.
comments.author: Vaskivskyi

comments.comment:
First I'd like to say that I used the HACS version of this integration and I really liked it. The config flow is one of the most complex I've seen and it provided a lot of helpful information from my router about my network.

I can't speak for this core implementation, but I had some serious performance issues with the custom component. I ended up running the profiler service in HA and it was clear it was this integration that was causing the issues, and even more clear running the profiler after disabling this integration.

I haven't had time to write up a detailed report, but I'd be happy to send over the profiler information.

Otherwise, I'd be cautious of the performance impact of this integration as it's the only integration I've ever had to disable due to performance reasons.
comments.author: Vaskivskyi
Vaskivskyi

comments.comment:
> Do I understand correctly that AsusWrt after implementing http(s) will have more or less the same capabilities as Asus Router?

Yes, it will use both old SSH library (for compatibility with old router / firmware) and HTTP for new router / firmware. I just put PR #71899 in draft because I didn't receive any feedback for long time and I completed development as custom component [here](https://github.com/ollo69/ha_asuswrt_custom), but I can reopen and complete that PR based on custom component if you think that this approach is the right one.
comments.author: Vaskivskyi

comments.comment:
I tested both custom integrations... and both work well and offer similar features. Asus Router creates more entities but the config flow is not user friendly. Hard to say which integration is better.

@ollo69 I think that splitting this change into smaller steps is much better approach. I will look at the first step #84152 this week.
comments.author: Vaskivskyi

comments.comment:
> Am I right that Asus Router integrations works with firmware 380 and newer?

Yes, that's correct. Actually it works with all the versions of Asus FW since the implementation of the native API (so, released in the last 12 or so years). This includes some of the 380.xx versions, even though not all of them

The same way I agree that having 2 integrations is not the best solution, I would like to point a problem of having a single integration with which user can have completely different set of sensors and controls depending on what they selected as a connection interface
comments.author: Vaskivskyi

comments.comment:
> First I'd like to say that I used the HACS version of this integration and I really liked it. The config flow is one of the most complex I've seen and it provided a lot of helpful information from my router about my network.
> 
> I can't speak for this core implementation, but I had some serious performance issues with the custom component. I ended up running the profiler service in HA and it was clear it was this integration that was causing the issues, and even more clear running the profiler after disabling this integration.

>

@ScottG489, as I have asked you on the Community forum, it would be nice to get from you at least some information about the device you are using (model and FW version), as well as some other details about the device settings.

AsusWRT firmware has some problems which might provide performance issue on the integration side - e.g. with hanging the connection sessions instead of closing or reporting them.

In order to help with your issue (and any other issue with AsusRouter custom integration), I need to be able to diagnose and troubleshoot which exactly part is not working properly

It is possible to have two integrations for the same brand.
The user must then select which one he wants to add:

When adding a config entry for Ikea, the user will be asked to decide which integration to add:

@Vaskivskyi Is it possible to detect which communication protocol should be used?
If yes I would suggest implementing it into the current one and during the config flow decide automatically which protocol should be used, completely transparent for the user. Imo at the end, the user wants to get the data into HA and does not matter, which protocol is used or what do you think?

comments.comment:
Hello and thanks for your feedback!

Yes, your suggestion is good. But this would require splitting the configuration for login/password (which will be handled by the re-auth flow and for which ConfigEntryAuthFailed can be raised properly) from the SLL / port settings as they are now.

Also, the credentials on the router do not expire as happens with some connected services and so on. The user needs to do this manually from the same menu as changing port/SSL - this was a part of the motivation to put them all together.

This can be implemented at the next step as a new feature and will help make the integration better. For now, I would prefer to keep the proposed code as small as possible, so the Core maintainers will be able to review it and approve it (if they find it correct and suitable).

Of course, if this plan is fine with you
comments.author: Vaskivskyi

comments.comment:
Because `format_mac` works only with MAC addresses. Also, the `router.mac` is already formatted using `format_mac` in `router.py` (line 137).

The commented code is used to convert the whole string to a predefined unique_id form (including `description.name`)

comments.comment:
This explanation makes no sense. If the device can't be reached, because it's unplugged, or because the user has flicked a physical on/off switch, it should be set to unavailable.

State off should be used if it's possible to call the `turn_on` service to turn the speaker on.

It seems to me like there's a bug related to handling errors which you need to fix. If Home Assistant loses connection to the speaker for whatever reason, Home Assistant should always automatically reconnect without user intervention such as reloading the config entry.
comments.author: fwestenberg

comments.comment: Instead of this, in particular because it's mentioned that there are issues related to reconnecting to the speaker, please look into the [data update coordinator](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/integration_fetching_data/#coordinated-single-api-poll-for-data-for-all-entities) which helps a great deal with error handling.
comments.author: fwestenberg

comments.comment:
It doesn't need to happen in __init__, it can happen in update:
```py
    async def async_update(self) -> None:
        """Get the latest details from the device."""
        await self._client.async_update()
        self._attr_media_album_name = self._client.media_album_name
        ...
```

This reduces the line count a great deal, which is a good thing

I see, but we should not work around typing issues by changing the code.
Instead, do something like this:
```py
assert entry.unique_id
self._attr_unique_id = entry.unique_id
```

Or just cast to a str
```py
self._attr_unique_id = cast(str, entry.unique_id)
```

comments.commit_message:
Use PidfdChildWatcher by default when available (#87951)

This is a backport from cpython 3.12

https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-policy.html
> PidfdChildWatcher is a “Goldilocks” child watcher implementation. It doesn’t require signals or threads, doesn’t interfere with any processes launched outside the event loop, and scales linearly with the number of subprocesses launched by the event loop. The main disadvantage is that pidfds are specific to Linux, and only work on recent (5.3+) kernels.

https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/98024
There are some additional fixes in cpython 3.12
in https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/94184
when there is no event loop running in the main thread
but this is not a problem we have

comments.comment:
Hi Lash,

I don't believe my account would get banned, as I have been testing this with my own doors for about 2 months now and I haven't received any disciplinary action.

If I could, I would make this a Cloud Push integration, but there's a weird bug where Linear just stops sending events entirely.

I'm worried the same would happen if I had a constant WebSocket open, it would stop sending events and it would break.
comments.author: IceBotYT

comments.comment:
Right now you haven't. But unless if i am misreading something you are logging in 17,280 times at a minimum each day since you log in each time the coordinator updates. and the coordinator is set to update every 5 seconds

If 100 people used this integration that's almost 2 million additional log ins a day. 1000 users, almost 20 million. 

They will probably have to investigate why there is a massive increase in usage of their authentication server and why it is under load, while there has not been a corresponding increase in customers. Then they will either ban accounts or build some functionality to stop you from doing it how you are doing it right now.

That is my opinion at least.
comments.author: IceBotYT

comments.comment: Given that they haven't updated the app in over 2 years, I think the team that develops the app doesn't care for their app anymore :(
