Please decrease it to something reasonable, maybe poll once per minute?

Logging in every time the cover is actuated seems OK, that won't happen often.

Unfortunately it looks like I might not be able to implement OAuth at all since [Trello only supports OAuth 1.0](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/trello/guides/rest-api/authorization/#using-basic-oauth) and I think we only [support OAuth 2.0](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/config_entries_config_flow_handler/#configuration-via-oauth2).

Can anyone confirm?

I'm chatting with their support to see if they have any plans to implement OAuth2. They already mentioned they're doing some changes to auth.
comments.author: ScottG489

comments.comment:
Regarding Trello supporting OAuth2 - support got back to me:

> [engineering does] have a project to make the Trello API support OAuth 2.0, it hasn't been scheduled yet, so we can't say for sure how soon that will be. It will happen though — eventually.

So OAuth2 is likely not going to happen with this PR, but as soon as it's available I'll definitely implement it in a follow up PR.

I can see where you're coming from with having to jump back and forth. I think it's more important to keep the `async_step` methods as readable as possible though. That's where the high level logic is and all the form definitions makes it much more difficult to grok. comments.comment:
Thanks, that's good to know. I still feel pretty strongly that this should be abstracted away into a method for readability in the `async_step` method. 

Otherwise, it does seem like `add_suggested_values_to_schema` would be appropriate to use here. However, looking at it again, I actually don't need to set defaults anymore since I've removed the options flow. So I'm removing the logic that would make `add_suggested_values_to_schema` necessary, but I'll definitely implement it in the follow up PR.
comments.author: ScottG489

comments.comment:
For readability I personally prefer using a sentinel value to short circuit. At least in this situation. There's less indentation and as you read the method from top to bottom there's less mental overhead since you can just forget what's above the short circuit conditional. In this situation it also reads more linearly since when running through the flow `user_input` being none is what happens first.

That said, I always thought it was pretty convoluted how flow steps were mixed like this. Now that I'm a little more familiar with the framework, I've made a refactor where the initial step is by itself. All the `user_input is None` checks kinda seem like an anti-pattern that's propagated the codebase. Then again, maybe I'm missing something!
comments.author: ScottG489

comments.comment: I ended up removing the defaulting behavior since it was only needed for the options flow so that won't be needed for now.
comments.author: ScottG489

comments.comment:
The big drawback of using a `dict` here is that you can't plainly see what information the config flow is gathering to use to create the config entry.

This could be cleaned up with a data object, but the values would still need to be initialized. In it's current state, I think there are few enough members where that abstraction isn't necessary quite yet, though.
comments.author: ScottG489

comments.comment: "API Key" and "API Token" are both preexisting naming in [`strings.json`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/5a18de67e5593cb965f3f343a0dfbbcde6b427e5/homeassistant/strings.json#L46-L47). Also "token" by itself could have other meanings, so I'd like to be explicit with what it's a token for.

comments.commit_message:
Initial Trello integration implementation

User enters credentials via config flow then selects 0-n boards they
would like to have card counts for each list on that board. There is
also an options flow where the user can add or remove boards freely.

For sensor updates, we not only use a coordinator to fetch all data at
once, we use Trello's REST API /batch endpoint to do so with a single
request. This is particularly important because of Trello's rate limits.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message: Add tests for new Trello integration

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Add module to strict typing

This also includes changes necessary to fulfill the strict-typing
requirements by adding type hints where necessary.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Remove Trello options flow and associated tests

It's extraneous for the initial PR and adds a lot of complexity. Will be
added back in a follow up PR.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Various refactoring fixes based on PR comments

- Replace member reference with new parameter to make method easier to
  reason about
- Rename flow step to better describe what it does
- last_step=True is redundant because by default the button will say
  "submit"
- Fix copy/paste problems with various docstrings
- Remove redundant TrelloEntity and move attributes to TrelloSensor
  subclass

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Remove logic to set preselected boards when prompting the user

Remove logic to set a default value when presenting a list of boards to
select. There will never be preselected boards when prompting the user
to select them since the options flow has been removed.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Refactor initial config flow step to be it's own method

This separates concerns so that each flow step method is responsible for
processing one form.

comments.author: ScottG489

Reference common string translations for config flow creds labels

Note that the "Token" label is changed to "API Token".

So that we're more consistent with key names for constants

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Update coordinator data every 60s

The coordinator was only updating on startup and it should be polling
for state changes.

I mistakenly thought 60s was the default when not specified.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Prompt user to select "Boards" not "Board names"

The user isn't choosing board names but rather selecting the boards
themselves they want to set up within the integration, so this wording
is more accurate.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Move helper method to be a factory class method

Move a helper method for creating a TrelloAdapter from creds to be a
factory class method instead.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Remove unused sensor update method

This method isn't needed when the native_value method is also being
used.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Set entities unavailable if there was a problem fetching their data

When there was a problem fetching data for a particular board, we had no
way to indicate to the sensors that there was a problem since we only
retained card count information in the coordinator data.

This change stores a richer set of data in the coordinator so the sensor
can mark itself as unavailable when appropriate.

- Use data from coordinator when setting up sensors rather than data
  stored in config entry. The config entry will soon be slimmed down to
  only contain configured board ids

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Change friendly name of list entity when changed in remote source

If the name of a Trello list was updated in Trello itself, we were not
reflecting this information the name locally. Now that we have richer
data being stored in the coordinator, we have access to this and when
the sensor updates so will the name.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Only save selected board ids into config entry

Previously we were saving board and list names in the config and using
this information to set up entities. However, some of this information
can change at run time.

Instead, we get this information from the coordinator and only save the
IDs of the boards the user selected.

comments.author: ScottG489

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Break out sensor availabilty and name calculation from native_value

I was advised that native_value should not be responsible for handling
the the calculation of these other values, so I've broken them out into
their appropriate methods.

Replace const defined for integration with preexisting global const

No need for us to define and use our own CONF_API_TOKEN const when this
const is already defined in the project-wide const file.

comments.author: ScottG489
comments.commit_message:
Make trello sensor tests more comprehensive

The sensor test is more of an integration test now where it tests the
full setup of the component and asserts on states actually pulled from
the state machine (hass). It also tests updates to the sensors and
ensures errors returned from the trello client are handled properly by
marking the corresponding sensor as unavailable.

This also makes the coordinator tests obsolete, so they have been
removed.

I think it would be good for the code owner to make it as a custom integration even just for testing. When I have created custom integrations while I waited for core PRs to get merged, it made testing changes a lot easier, as people could immediately try them out.

comments.comment:
Hello @xeniter,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:


- [`462c8edc0c2a804f8d8a8d612c37b4800122d0c1`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/93750/commits/462c8edc0c2a804f8d8a8d612c37b4800122d0c1) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (manuel.dipolt@robart.cc). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.


Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting "Author Name" and "`email@address.com`" for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

comments.comment:
Hello @xeniter,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:


- [`eefded8501697d97adbb7c0e61197366383f3647`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/93750/commits/eefded8501697d97adbb7c0e61197366383f3647) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (manuel.dipolt@robart.cc). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.


Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting "Author Name" and "`email@address.com`" for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:
comments.author: xeniter

comments.comment:
This is because you are referencing the climate entity in the coordinator (and the climate entity requires the coordinator). If I understand correctly you are doing this because the coordinator can discover new devices and add them on the go.

Other integrations solve this by doing stuff with listeners, for example the hue integration:

https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/25a80cd46f0c51f675294f859ee797d9081989a8/homeassistant/components/hue/v2/light.py#L53-L66

This way you don't have to bother the coordinator with creating entities, and you are not bothering entity platforms with how the data is created. This would be more extendable and easier to extend

comments.comment:
@chamberlain2007 The problem is that it's misleading and confusing to derive a class from `DataUpdateCoordinator` and then go ahead and not use a single functionality of that class except for `async_add_listener`.

What you could do instead is to derive your coordinator from `BaseDataUpdateCoordinatorProtocol` and your entities from `BaseCoordinatorEntity`.
comments.author: chamberlain2007

comments.comment:
> @chamberlain2007 The problem is that it's misleading and confusing to derive a class from `DataUpdateCoordinator` and then go ahead and not use a single functionality of that class except for `async_add_listener`.
> 
> What you could do instead is to derive your coordinator from `BaseDataUpdateCoordinatorProtocol` and your entities from `BaseCoordinatorEntity`.

Thanks for this feedback. I went ahead and made that change. I did need to lift `async_add_listener` and `async_update_listeners` to make this work. I removed anything but the bare minimum needed.

Nice, but there are several other places where you also use `data[Attribute.MAC_ADDRESS]` to create devices and so on.
You can just use the config entry's unique ID there instead.

Please take a look at that and mark the PR ready for review when done.

Also, after a reconnect to the device, I think it would be a good idea to check the MAC and call `self.config_entry.async_start_reauth(self.hass)` if not matching. You could add this in a PR adding a reauth flow though.

comments.comment:
Apologies for the 11th hour request. 

I noticed that the ‘humidifier’ entity isn’t being used for the Humidifier or Dehumidifier integrations. And the ‘weather’ entity isn’t being used for the outside temp and humidity sensors. The Ecobee integration is a great example of both integrations. 

It would be great if these were added in for the initial release, or at the very least a fast follow to reduce as many migrations as possible farther down the line. @chamberlain2007 

Other integrations such as Aux/Emergency heat can be added in later without worrying about migration of entities later.
comments.author: chamberlain2007

> 
> I noticed that the ‘humidifier’ entity isn’t being used for the Humidifier or Dehumidifier integrations. And the ‘weather’ entity isn’t being used for the outside temp and humidity sensors. The Ecobee integration is a great example of both integrations.

> 
> Other integrations such as Aux/Emergency heat can be added in later without worrying about migration of entities later.

The Home Assistant team prefers starting an integration with a minimal set of functionality, hence this only containing the climate entity. If you use the other entities, I would recommend staying with the unofficial version until everything is implemented here.

comments.comment:
@IsakNyberg It's not ideal, but the reason is that the thermostats are very flaky, and too many socket requests in a short period of time can completely overload it and cause it to need a restart. Because I need to establish the connection to validate it during the config flow and then immediately let it disconnect, and then reconnect again right after when the integration is setup, I am concerned about overloading it. So, I added a `sleep` here to avoid that case.

If you have any other suggestions, open to changing it!

comments.comment: Don't we want to replace the existing integration and reuse that domain and import the configuration.yaml to the config flow via an import step?
comments.author: ColinCampbell

comments.comment:
> Don't we want to replace the existing integration and reuse that domain and import the configuration.yaml to the config flow via an import step?

I think that would be a good idea since I don't think the current one works at all given https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/decora has 0 installs
comments.author: ColinCampbell

comments.comment: Are there examples of integrations that do that? I thought about doing trying to reuse the existing integration. My concern is that at some point between the old integration being written and now, Leviton changed the format of the API key the device firmware expects, and the API key is stored in the old `configuration.yaml` files. Anything ported from the old integration to this new one would need to be re-added or at the very least re-authenticated. That, and the fact that there were 0 installs of the old integration, I wasn't sure that the additional effort to try and port over existing usages would be worth it.
comments.author: ColinCampbell

comments.comment:
How does the user get the api key with the old method vs the new method?

Is there a way the old key can be converted into the new format?
comments.author: ColinCampbell

comments.comment:
The switch is put into a pairing mode by pressing and hold down on the switch paddle for a few seconds, then the system communicating with it over Bluetooth is able to ask for the API key. As far as I know, there's no conversion method to go from old API keys to new ones. My devices were already on the most recent version of the firmware when I bought them and everything I was able to find about connecting to the devices since the firmware upgrade required repairing the devices.

Edit: happy to defer in terms of actually making a decision on whether this is worth it. I should have time to code something up. This is the first time I've worked in the Home Assistant codebase though so I'm not 100% on what is possible etc
comments.author: ColinCampbell

comments.comment:
Maybe import the device data to config entries without validating the api key, and then when the config entry is setup it will fail authentication and a reauth flow can be started which will ask the user to put the device in pairing mode to re-authenticate?

https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/config_entries_config_flow_handler#reauthentication

You can search for `async_step_import` in the repo for integrations that import data via the config flow to config entries.
comments.author: ColinCampbell

I've started implementing the import and reauth steps! I'm travelling this week so it might be a bit before an update.

Another question, I'm not sure I'll be able to get my device downgraded to past firmware to check that the new bleak-based package I wrote works with previous firmware versions. I can double check the code in communicating with the switches, but is there any prior art and/or hard or soft rules on changing integrations that require upgrading device firmware?
comments.author: ColinCampbell

comments.comment:
> I've started implementing the import and reauth steps! I'm travelling this week so it might be a bit before an update.

I've set the PR as draft pending your update. Please don't forget to click the "ready for review" button once you've implemented import of old configurations.

> I can double check the code in communicating with the switches, but is there any prior art and/or hard or soft rules on changing integrations that require upgrading device firmware?

If the firmware us user upgradeable, I don't see any problems with requiring the user to do a firmware upgrade. If you can't test it yourself, I'd suggest to block old firmware already in the config flow if possible, and just ask the user to upgrade the device.

comments.comment:
AC number should never change, unless physical changes have been done to the AC system (adding or removing a ducted AC unit).
This is not something that would normally happen.
comments.author: danzel

comments.comment: They are similar systems made by the same manufacturer. They have different protocols and behaviours.
comments.author: danzel

comments.comment:
Not quite. Airtouch 5 is a ducted AC system.
There is one physical AC unit (represented in HA as `Airtouch5AC`).
The air output of this unit is ducted in to multiple rooms, each of which has a damper (to control flow rate) and a temperature sensor. These are represented as an `Airtouch5Zone`.
A zone reports its current temperature, can be turned on and off individually, and you can set the target temperature for it individually.

In HA it ends up looking like:
![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/393086/bd247c5d-6a8d-454a-8895-85cf8ea7e12c)
You can set heat/cool mode on the AC unit, and turn each zone on/off by settings them to "Fan only" or "Off".

This mirrors `airtouch4` and `advantage_air`.
comments.author: danzel

comments.comment:
How should this be handled?
Are we meant to keep trying to connect in the background, or return a specific error?
At the moment if we fail to connect here HA reports that we failed to load and you have to reload the integration.

If we're meant to keep trying to connect in the background, how should I handle that we don't know what entities we have until we have connected?
Feel free to just point me at another component that does this nicely.

I've taken a look around in other components, `azure_event_hub` will raise a `ConfigEntryNotReady` if it fails to connect during `async_setup_entry`. Is that what you are thinking?

I really appreciate your help here.
comments.author: danzel

comments.comment: It depends  which kind of error it is. A temporary connection error than raise `ConfigEntryNotReady`. If the error is persistent, please raise `ConfigEntryError`
comments.author: danzel

comments.comment:
Looks like if you throw ConfigEntryNotReady here, home assistant will handle the retry for you
